PETITION.TITLE: ANU and CSIRO: Fellowships
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showed that:

1.Many Australians agree with the stated aim of the Australian Research Fellowship and Senior Fellowship, namely to encourage the return of world class expatriate researchers, to support high quality research and to develop research skills fundamental to the nations national interest with the aim of boosting Australia's research and technology push.

PARA.TAB: And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensioners: Shares
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned shows:
The legislation passed in December 1992 to count the increases in the value of shares held by pensioners as income, even if the shares are never sold to realise the gain:
(1) Is unjust.
(2) Has its most detrimental effect on pensioners with small holdings.
(3) Only affects Australian Stock Exchange listed shares.
(4) Discourages small scale investment in Australian companies.
Your Petitioners request that the amendments in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (no 3) 1992 relating to unrealised capital gains on shares should be repealed.
And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Drugs
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth; that we support your efforts to strengthen our family and community life particularly by increased penalties for "drug pushers" and distributors. We, however, wish to register our firm opposition to any legal changes which would increase or encourage the distribution or availability of so-called "soft drugs" such as marijuana. We believe such drugs to be harmful to the physical and psychological health of the individual and therefore to the interest of the community of which such individual is part. Although there is current controversy concerning the question of such harm it appears to us quite foolish to legalise and encourage the use of such drugs unless or until it be shown that such drugs are in fact harmless. The serious social problems of alcohol should provide sufficient warning to our society.
Any efforts to legalise or decriminalise usage or distribution of such drugs will have the following results:

PARA.TAB: 1. Encourage and inculcate a social acceptability towards such drugs.
2. Increase the volume of usage of such drugs in schools and the community by present users and by "drug pushers" through the proposed one ounce legal possession.
3. Extend the usage of such drugs to persons who would previously have abstained because of the legal sanctions.

4. Put pressure upon Parliament to establish and license import, growth, manufacture and/or distribution of such drugs, that is, to regulate another destructive industry contrary to the best interest of the individual and society.
5. There would be the probable temptation to tax such drugs as another source of Federal revenue.

We urge the Government to increase the medical and counselling facilities for the assistance of drug users and to expand existing Drug Referral Centres and Clinics. We have general confidence in the existing law and its sympathetic implementation by the Police and Courts.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that your honourable House will firstly take no measures that could extend the major social problem of drug usage and secondly will oblige those who are promoting marijuana and/or similar drugs to prove without doubt that such drugs are harmless before any legalisation or decriminalisation of use is introduced. And your petitioners as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:
We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia should retain the current National Flag which has flown over the country since Federation. This flag
symbolises the world's oldest democracy
represents our history, our culture and our language
enjoys the support of the vast majority of the Australian people
symbolises the sacrifice of our armed servicemen and women
Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should retain the current national flag.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Influenza Vaccine
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The humble petition of we, the undersigned citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
We wish to draw your attention to the urgent need for funding for the recently released Hib vaccine. Hib disease causes suffering, death and permanent disability in babies and young children.

The Hib vaccine is recommended by the NH&MRC for all babies and children from the ages of 2 months to 5 years. It is to be added to the routine immunization schedule and is the first significant addition since measles in 1968. All other routine vaccinations are free.

The Hib vaccine is presently only available to those who can afford to pay for it on a user pays basis. This will effectively result in many babies and children remaining at risk of contracting the Hib disease. This is a social justice issue.
We believe it is inappropriate to add this vaccine to the recommended schedule when it is unfunded or only partially funded.
We are asking that this vaccine be made accessible to all babies and children from 2 months to 5 years of age. Please fully fund this new Hib vaccine for all Australian children.
Your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 19 May, on motion by Senator Sowada:
That Regulation 51 of the Austudy Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1992 No. 399 and made under the Student Assistance Act 1973, be disallowed.

TALK.START.PARA: —When speaking to this motion on 19 May I made the point that due consideration ought to be given by the Government and by the Opposition to the points that were advanced in support of the disallowance by Senator Sowada and, if they would be kind enough, to the points that I was making. I am now even more convinced of the justification for Senator Sowada's motion.

PARA.TAB: The disallowance is an attempt to rectify what we see as discrimination, particularly against families who have a number of sons and daughters in secondary or tertiary education. Regulation 51 says that students are not entitled to Austudy that is $1,000 or less per annum. As was indicated in the debate on 19 May, this will impact quite seriously on a family which contains three or four students. In respect of Austudy, this regulation would reduce the income of a family with four students by $4,000, minus $4—in other words, by $3,996. That is not chickenfeed when it comes to a family trying to make ends meet. As I mentioned on 19 May, it does not fit comfortably with the Government's policy—and, indeed, with the policy of the Opposition—and the general desire of the Australian community to encourage young people to acquire skills so that they will be able to obtain jobs and enhance their creative capacities.

The Government may say, `Well, this particular proposition will not deter persons from pursuing that objective'. It may also say that, in its view, it is too costly to continue the current process of paying on a regular basis that amount up to $1,000 a year. The Government relies fairly heavily on the Chapman report and on an Australian youth survey conducted by DEET in 1990 which showed that when it came to Austudy of $25 or less per week the proportion of parents who said their children needed it to stay at school was rather small.

It is not apparent from this document whether the parents understood that that $25 per week meant $25 per student or $25 per family. Because of the operation of two factors—the present sibling concession and the operation of regulation 51, which Senator Sowada is seeking to disallow—a family with four students could be affected by as much as $3,996 a year.

The Government will say, `Well, if two of those students are secondary students, family payments can be claimed in respect of them'. Even so, there would be a gap of around $10 a week. The difference between Austudy and a family payment of $1,000 per annum would be about $10 a week. Families would still be losing roughly $500 a year per student. Then the Government might say, `Well, in respect of those students who are receiving less than $1,000 a year, the operation of the regulations would enable those students to take out a loan of $1,000 a year'. They lose $999 and are told they can get a loan for $1,000. To be quite frank, that is of small comfort. That loan, as we know, will need to be repaid if the student is able to obtain employment. Once the remuneration for that employment has reached about $27,000 a year, then the repayments, as I understand it, start to operate at a rate of about two per cent.

Those responses by the Government do not in any way deter me from my very strenuous support for Senator Sowada's disallowance motion, particularly as it attempts to rectify what is seen as discrimination against larger families.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I have already indicated on the coalition's behalf that we do not support Senator Sowada's motion for disallowance. When I spoke previously, I outlined as carefully as I could the reasons for this. Those reasons remain persuasive in the view of the coalition.

PARA.TAB: During the course of the debate on this motion, Senator Harradine very genuinely—and I think with Senator Sowada's nodding approval—appealed to the chamber and not least the coalition to give consideration to the effect that this cut-off would have on families which have more than one child. He asked us to consider whether there would be a harsher effect on families with more than one child undertaking secondary or tertiary studies. I rise only briefly to say that we listened carefully to that appeal. We are aware that that is why this debate has been deferred until today.

My colleague Mr Andrews, the shadow Minister for schools and training, who is responsible for matters concerning student allowances, has had careful discussions with my coalition colleagues. We remain opposed to Senator Sowada's disallowance motion because the disallowance affects all Austudy students, not just those who are members of a family with a number of students.

I want to make three brief points. The Government has responded to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. It has also responded to the Chapman report. In the case of Austudy, a sibling concession in terms of adjusted family income is already in place. For a dependent student over the age of 16 in receipt of Austudy, the adjusted family income is $3,700 more than it would be if there were only one Austudy student in a family. In the case of students under 16 years old, for the first sibling the allowance is an additional $1,200 in terms of the adjusted family income and $2,500 for siblings beyond that.

Senator Harradine referred to cases where four students in a family are receiving Austudy. There is already a concession in relation to an adjustment to family income which seeks to take that into account. In so far as there is any shortfall in the benefit to such families, the Government ought to take into account what has been said in this debate and, in due course, bring back to the Senate any regulation that would be fairer to families with a number of children receiving Austudy.

I am aware also of the answers that have been given to Senator Harradine with regard to questions he asked at recent estimates hearings relating to Austudy and its effect upon families with a number of students receiving Austudy. Senator Harradine wanted to know the effect of combining tax and Austudy withdrawal rates on such families. There are very sharp cut-offs, and there is a counterproductive impact upon families with many children. These matters also ought to be considered by the Government. I repeat on behalf of the coalition that we do not support Senator Sowada's disallowance motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank honourable senators for their contribution. I particularly thank Senator Teague and the Opposition for giving us the time to discuss this issue. I thank them for having the courtesy to listen to our arguments and I hope that they did find them in some way persuasive. Likewise, I thank the Government, particularly the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training, Mr Free, for taking the time to meet with Senator Harradine and me. I am still very disappointed that the Opposition will not be supporting this disallowance motion. I believe that the arguments we have put are persuasive. The regulation clearly affects thousands and thousands of students currently in secondary school.

PARA.TAB: I will briefly respond to some of the arguments that have been put to us in this debate. The report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training and the Chapman report have been referred to. I make the point that the House of Representatives report—the Price report—did suggest that small amounts of Austudy would not affect the capacity of a family to actually send their child to school. This may well be the case in the broader sense, although I wonder whether the House of Representatives committee absolutely understands the desperate need of so many families in Australia at present.

During the inquiry into youth unemployment conducted by the Senate Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training we came across a lot of information and evidence which suggested that, whilst parents may still be struggling to send their children to school, the costs involved in that education are enormous. I made reference to this last week in the debate on this motion for disallowance. The cost involved in educating a child—for example, school excursions, uniforms, books and the cost of elective courses where there is a practical content—is in some cases beyond the reach of struggling families.

I refer the Senate to page 152 of the Senate standing committee report, Wanted: our future, which indicated that privately funded programs are now run by the Smith Family and other organisations to actually assist families with these extra costs. The `Edu-cate' program essentially provides scholarships to young people to help meet the costs associated with their education. It is precisely these kinds of costs that smaller amounts of Austudy would seek to cover.

The Government has also told us in briefings that those families who lose this particular Austudy payment will qualify for the basic family payment of $10.35. However, that is still a loss of some $9.65 per week to those families. Once again, that represents an enormous amount of money not coming into the family budget over a year.

I say to the Government that there must be better ways of doing this. Why a lump sum payment could not be considered is beyond me. It seems beyond the capacity of the bureaucrats and the Government to dream up a scheme that would make payment administratively more simple. I recall that one of the reasons why the Government put forward this particular restriction last year was to save on administrative costs. We accept, as I said last week, that there are certainly some savings to be made, but again, that was all too difficult.

Is it possible for the Government, in conjunction with DEET, to devise a scheme whereby perhaps there could be a minimum of $1,000 per family as opposed to a minimum of $1,000 per child? That is another measure that could be taken into account if we see some further amendments to Austudy regulations.

We have heard the argument that the Government has responded to the Chapman report. The Government has gone part of the way towards implementing some of the recommendations of the Chapman report—the ones that save it some money and the ones that make it look as though it has fiddled around the edges with some of the recommendations—but it has not fully implemented some of the recommendations, although issues such as the loans scheme and so forth very quickly found their way into the budget.

With those few words—without wanting to prolong the agony on this matter any further—I simply say that I am very disappointed that the Opposition has not seen fit to support us in this measure. Once again, the Government continues to implement measures in the Fightback package. We will be watching the Budget that will be tabled in August very closely to see how far this Government is prepared to continue to implement Fightback measures, especially in the areas of education, health and social welfare. In my view, we have not seen the end of this insidious piece of government policy making. I urge the Australian public likewise to be vigilant and ensure that it has not elected a conservative government by stealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —The measures contained in the Insolvency (Tax Priorities) Legislation Amendment Bill were announced by way of a joint press release from the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and the then Attorney-General on 2 December 1992. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that there has been a five-year gestation period between the introduction of the measures in this Bill and their recommendation by the Law Reform Commission.

PARA.TAB: This Bill has had a curious introduction to the Parliament. Prior to these sittings it was listed for introduction in the autumn session and was then withdrawn at some stage, unbeknown to me. Then, last Wednesday, 19 May 1993, the Bill was introduced precipitately by Senator McMullan, with the apparent expectation that it could be debated the next day. In any event, we find ourselves debating it today, but one can only wonder at the motivation behind this sort of behaviour.

I am also concerned at the lack of opportunity given to outsiders to participate in a scrutiny debate of this Bill. This lack of opportunity is unfortunate, given representations from outside groups, including the Law Council of Australia, which believes that this Bill should not be introduced in its present form until the Law Council has had an opportunity to look at its various provisions. The insolvency practitioners group is of like mind. However, at the same time I must say that the Bill is properly motivated and its intention quite desirable.

This Bill contains major amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act and, consequent on these primary amendments, it also amends a number of other Acts, including the Corporations Law, the Bankruptcy Act 1966, the Crown Debts (Priority) Act 1981 and the Crimes (Taxation Offences) Act 1980. The background to this Bill is found in the priority accorded to the payment of certain of the debts to the commissioner over all other debts in the post-bankruptcy or insolvency division of assets. The only exceptions to this priority attach to the costs of a trustee in bankruptcy and fees properly incurred in the administration of the insolvent estate.

Sections 221P, 221YHJ, 221YHZD and 221YU of the Income Tax Assessment Act are the specific sections which accord the commissioner priority for the respective following debts: first, unremitted tax instalment deductions in respect of an employee's salary and wages; second, unremitted deductions of tax made in respect of the prescribed payments system; and, third, unremitted withholding tax in respect of a natural resource payment, a royalty payment, dividends or interest paid to a non-resident.

The priority has been the subject of criticism and much litigation over its period of existence. It has most often been criticised on the obvious ground that, after the tax office has satisfied its claims, there is little or nothing to pay to the former employees for their basic entitlements or to pay to unsecured creditors for their debts. The size of the debt to the ATO is often exacerbated by the ATO's slowness to act to recoup the money owed, such lack of urgency being a result of the tax office's guaranteed return through the existing priority. Obviously, as the tax office delays and the debt grows, the residual for others diminishes accordingly.

Despite the hardships created by priority, it does have a logical justification in that the unpaid amounts are not in truth the assets of the company but simply employees' taxes held by the company as the unpaid tax collector. The problem arises because, as an enterprise falls into financial difficulties, occasionally the company's management or directors—who apparently, like the rest of us, can resist anything except temptation—may use these deducted moneys as emergency working capital. That is the nub of the problem.

However, it should be remembered that, while the priority is defensible as a matter of law, such reasoning is of little comfort to the employees. A second problem with the priority has arisen with the recently announced new insolvency procedure through voluntary administration. This procedure is designed to allow a company to trade out of financial difficulties under an administrator. Creditors, who must assent to the arrangement—which involves a moratorium on debts for all creditors—are unlikely to do so if the only probable beneficiary of this particular arrangement is the Australian Taxation Office. In the current environment there is a need to remove the priority of the tax office.

I now turn to the provisions of the Bill. The clauses of this Bill basically fall into four parts: first, the abolition of the commissioner's priority in insolvency in respect of the four categories of unremitted amounts; secondly, the provision of a new method whereby the commissioner may recover any unremitted amounts by estimating the amount due, such estimate automatically creating a recoverable debt; thirdly, the extension of liability, beyond any that may exist under the insolvent trading provisions in the Corporations Law, for the unremitted amounts to company directors in certain circumstances; fourthly, consequent amendments to the Corporations Law and other legislation.

I now wish to deal with each of these four issues in turn. The first is the abolition of the commissioner's priority. This is achieved by a simple removal, from the four sections of the Income Tax Assessment Act that accord the priority, of the trustee's liability in insolvency for deductions made in respect of the four categories of payment after 30 June 1993. This removal is effected by the insertion of four new subsections—clauses 7, 9, 11 and 15 of the Bill. As priority is accorded to the particular debts outlined earlier for which the trustee is liable, the removal of this liability from the priority provisions correspondingly removes the priority, rendering these sections obsolete for deductions made after 30 June 1993. Priority will remain for amounts due and payable before 1 July 1993 while the trustee's ordinary liability to the tax office is preserved by an extension of section 215 to include the relevant unremitted amounts.

Put simply, debts due to the commissioner as a result of failure to remit the deductions will be treated on the same basis as debts payable to other unsecured creditors upon the entity being placed into some form of insolvency administration, that is, by the rateable application of the insolvent estate's assets. However, this is assuming that the tax office is owed any of these debts when the company falls into insolvency. The new estimates procedure for recovery of unremitted amounts is intended to avoid this contingency as far as possible.

The second category is the new recovery procedure by estimation of unremitted amounts. We have absolutely no problem with the first category. The second category inserts a new division, division 8, part VI, of the Income Tax Assessment Act. The purpose of this new division, as stated in section 222AFA, is to enable the commissioner to make an estimate of the unremitted amounts. The estimate creates a separate liability to any that might otherwise exist and so provides a basis for recovery of the estimated amount.

When then can the commissioner make an estimate? Is there any mandated basis for this estimate? The new section 222AGA(1) provides that the commissioner may make a reasonable estimate if he has reason to suspect that a liability under a remittance provision has not been discharged after the due date for such payment. It is further provided that the commissioner may—significantly, not shall—have regard to anything he thinks relevant in making that estimate.

Aside from the requirement that the estimate be reasonable, the width of the discretion afforded to the commissioner is apparent. There is, for example, no requirement that the estimate be based on an extrapolation of what reasonably would be due, predicated upon past remittances of a particular taxpayer. Further, it would seem that the qualification that the estimate be reasonable is meaningless in that clause 19 of the Bill purports to exclude any decisions of the commissioner concerning estimates from judicial review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. The only circumstances in which an estimate must be revoked or reduced is upon the person in receipt of the estimate notice providing a statutory declaration attesting to the amount of the liability. The liability to pay the amount of the estimate, which arises immediately upon the issuing of a notice, is created by section 222AHA(1), with 222AHA(2) providing that a liability to pay an estimate is separate and distinct from the liability to which the estimate relates. However, payment of one liability will correspondingly reduce the other.

If the amount paid to discharge the estimate exceeds the unpaid amount of the actual liability, then the commissioner must either refund the excess, or apply to, against any other liabilities of that particular person. This last option may allow the commissioner to avoid having to seek to execute a judgment for a debt. If it is accepted that the issuance of an assessment creates a liability, then this provision is of even wider benefit to the commissioner.

Section 222AHC provides for an affidavit, if it attests to certain things, by the defendant to constitute a defence to recovery of the estimate. An estimate will be provable in a bankruptcy or a winding-up. A penalty regime will operate if an estimate remains undischarged after seven days from the issuance of the notice. Penalties will be on the same terms as would apply to failure to pay the underlying liability. The commissioner is given a wide discretion to make an agreement for the discharge of liability by payment by instalments.

The third classification is penalties for directors of non-remitting companies. Here lie a number of problems. A further new division, division 9, is added to the Income Tax Assessment Act by the Bill to ensure either that the relevant payments are made or that the company concerned goes into liquidation or voluntary liquidation forthwith. This scheme is intended to prevent PAYE, et cetera, moneys being used as emergency working capital and is consonant with the observation that the commissioner's priority places no pressure on companies to remit taxes because it only operates once the company is placed in some form of insolvency administration. The idea is to prevent defalcations occurring or escalating.

The scheme's purpose is achieved by making the directors personally liable under section 222AOC for the company's failure to pay if none of the three options for payment, voluntary administration or liquidation are taken up. It must be accepted that the imposition of these duties by section 222AOB is necessary to make the estimates procedure workable. However, section 222AOC provides that any person who is a director at any time during the period from which the liability to remit arose, that is, when the deduction was made, until the date when the payment is due, will be liable to pay to the commissioner an amount equal to the unpaid amount of the company's liability. That is quite preposterous.

In other words, a director who is unable to convince the board to undertake one of the mandated options under section 222AOB(1) so as to comply with the tax office's demands and resigns from the board could still be liable for the whole of the amount of the unpaid tax should his fellow directors prove to be men of straw. This would be despite his having acted in good faith throughout. Even allowing for contributory or indemnity rights under section 222AOI, a liability proportionate to the number on the board is a misplaced penalty.

The defences available to directors under this division are outlined in section 222A0J and are too vague to be adequate, in my opinion. In particular, it will be a defence if a director can show that he took all reasonable steps to ensure that deductions were remitted or that there were no such steps that the director could take. It is simply not clear whether this section extends to protect a director who has acted in good faith. Whether it is thought that the Federal Court would make this extension is irrelevant. Such a protection for directors who act properly must be an explicit one. Sections 222APB to 222API reiterate the above provisions relating to company directors for estimated liability penalties.

The fourth area of amendment is to the Corporations Law. The Corporations Law is amended to the extent necessary to coordinate the operation of the new voluntary administration procedure with the measures in this Bill. For this reason, clause 21 of the Bill introduces a new section 443BA, which extends an administrator's liability for debts incurred during the period the company is under administration to amounts of tax due under a remittance provision. Further, section 459E is amended to allow an estimate as the basis for a statutory demand. The commissioner will also be allowed to take advantage of the recently amended insolvent trading provisions by the inclusion of liabilities under a remittance provision as debts under section 588F.

So a wholly new section, section 588FGA, is added so as to make the directors personally liable to indemnify the commissioner should the court set aside a payment of a relevant amount because of the commissioner's constructive or actual knowledge of the insolvency of the person making the disposition. Other creditors who have dispositions made to them voided in a similar way do not have an extraordinary avenue of recourse against the directors personally.

There is no good reason why the commissioner should enjoy this special right of indemnity. The culpability which constructive or actual knowledge carries and which grounds the court's avoidance of the payment is the same for the commissioner as it is for any other preferred creditor. We have a great deal of concern about this provision. One can go to the court and get a judgment, yet it does not stand so far as the commissioner is concerned. This avoids the whole purpose and intent of the thrust of the Bill. It is internally inconsistent.

There are three limbs to what this Bill seeks to achieve. Firstly, it seeks to ensure that employees' entitlements and the rights of unsecured creditors, which may otherwise have been lost, are protected, and that is a good measure. This is a change that is sustainable for the pragmatic reason that the Consolidated Revenue is better able to sustain a reduction of the proceeds from an insolvency administration than employees or unsecured creditors might be. The pain caused to employees who have been left with nothing after the collapse of their employer and to unsecured creditors who have had to write off huge losses because of the failure of a major debtor should not be underestimated. We also should not forget who is responsible for this economic trauma and that it has taken five years to bring about these changes.

Secondly, the abolition of the priority will remove what may have been a cause of the new voluntary administration scheme falling into a heap almost immediately upon its introduction. Thirdly, the Bill will provide, by way of a new estimates procedure, for a more effective way of collecting unremitted amounts held by entities on behalf of the commissioner as unpaid tax collectors and for a means to force company directors to confront insolvency problems before being tempted to use deducted amounts as emergency working capital.

Broadly, the coalition supports the thrust of this Bill and considers that a reasonable balance has been struck between protecting moneys which, after all, belong rightly to the revenue, and allowing for some equity to employees and creditors of the failed enterprises. But a number of problems with this Bill as it presently stands are very worrying. These are matters that I believe should be thoroughly examined by a properly constituted scrutiny of the Bill. This has been denied to this Parliament, even though it would enable people outside the Parliament to make a contribution.

Another oversight which is not addressed by the Bill or the explanatory memorandum is the duty of the Australian Taxation Office, under section 221Q, to credit an employee with an amount of tax equal to the amount deducted from the employee's salary or wages when the employer has made such deductions but has failed to issue a group certificate or deliver tax stamps in respect of the employee's salary or wages. The interaction of the new estimates procedure with section 221Q, which is an existing provision, has not been addressed. It is not clear whether the issue of an estimate will grant the benefit of the estimated amount due in tax to employees.

In my opinion, it would be inexcusable if a Bill such as this, which effects major changes to income tax law and the Corporations Law, were allowed to be passed by this place without detailed and further consideration of its ramifications. There has not yet been any opportunity for wide and proper consultation with the members of the community who may be affected by this Bill. These people are expecting such an opportunity. If the Senate, because of an unfortunate agreement between the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats, agrees to this abortion of a procedure between a quarter to one and 2 o'clock today, there will be no opportunity for that outside participation.

I believe that we will see many amendments to this Bill. It is poor legislation. The intention is right but, in typical Keating fashion, the Government is tagging on some very unsatisfactory features that the Law Council and professional bodies are very concerned about. When Bills are rushed through in the latter stages of the sittings, proper consideration is not given to the concerns of people outside the Parliament or to the proper parliamentary scrutiny process.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Insolvency (Tax Priorities) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 proposes a major reform of the law and practice of the recovery by the Commissioner of Taxation of certain unremitted moneys and outstanding debts. The proposal was announced on 2 December last year by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) and the then Attorney-General in a joint press release.

PARA.TAB: At the moment section 221P of the Income Tax Assessment Act grants absolute priority to the tax commissioner over all other debts where an employer has failed to remit tax instalments or PPS deductions deducted from employee's wages, and a receiver or liquidator has been appointed. Where an employer pays wages to employees, deducts tax from their wages and does not remit the tax to the tax office, then that debt to the tax commissioner is granted priority against all other debts whether preferential, secured or unsecured.

The debt still has to be proven in the usual manner; however, once it is proven it assumes priority. The reason for this provision is quite straightforward. It is designed to ensure that group tax is paid or, in the official terminology, to protect the revenue. The Government has decided to formally remove the priority, but only in respect of amounts that should have been remitted before 30 June 1993. So the reform is prospective from the end of this financial year only.

The reason for the abolition is probably industrial in nature. We are aware that last year there were some vigorous complaints from various unions about the unfair nature of the priority. The major instances occur in the textiles industry and the building industry where subcontractors perform some work but do not get paid because the main contractor has collapsed. The subcontractors are creditors of the contractor and queue up with the other creditors, for example banks, to try to get paid. In this instance, if the contractor has not remitted its group tax or PPS deductions, then the tax commissioner obtains priority and often takes all the money. The net effect of that action is that subcontractors do a lot of work but do not get paid for it. This measure is fair to employees and other creditors and the Democrats support that.

Despite the claims made by Mr George Gear in a recent press release, I think we also have to realise and acknowledge that the Government is not being all that generous in this measure. The existing law is quite narrowly drawn in the sense that it can apply only where the employer is in financial trouble. There have been a myriad of cases which actually define when the priority is applicable, and there have been many defeats for the commissioner. Careful business practice can often subvert the priority anyway.

The President of the Insolvency Practitioners of Australia, Mr Michael Mount, was reported as supporting the abolition of the priority before the Government's announcement last December. Indeed, he is also reported as saying that this section has built more beach houses and holiday retreats for lawyers than any other tax law. With the repeal of the priority, it is important that other systems are put in place to ensure that the tax laws are complied with. Consequently, the Bill also proposes to quite radically overhaul the current recovery procedures. Recovery action is that administrative action to actually bring in the amounts which are owed to the tax commissioner. It must be remembered that establishing a liability does not actually ensure that the liability is met by the taxpayer. Very often taxpayers have to be pursued through the courts and this is often both slow and expensive.

At the moment, the commissioner is required to establish the precise amount of the unremitted moneys before he can take legal action to recover the amount. This means that there is always a delay between the date of non-remittance and the time of ascertainment of the amount before any recovery action can actually commence. The Bill attacks this problem by using the mechanism of allowing the commissioner to estimate the amount that should have been remitted and suing to recover that amount. This will occur only after the amounts should have been remitted, so it is not putting any additional onus on employers; it will simply ensure that the procedure for those who are in default works more quickly. One could argue that this will increase the efficiency and speed of the recovery processes.

The Bill also proposes to increase the penalties applied to directors who do not remit the proper amounts of tax to the Tax Office. They will be personally liable for the amounts which are not remitted. The principle here is quite simple. At no time is the tax ever the property of the directors; it is the income of the worker and it is claimed by the government as a prepayment of an employee's tax liability for the year. If the directors do not fulfil the duty to remit the money to the Tax Office, basically they are committing theft. The same consideration applies to superannuation funds, which the committee has looked at.

Senator Watson has drawn our attention to the consternation that this penalty provision for directors is causing in some circles. I think he is suggesting that it cannot be sufficiently investigated in the hearing of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration which is proposed for today. It is true that it deserves sufficient time for consideration. The committee might even recommend some amendments. But there is one easy way for directors to avoid the problem, and that is to remit the taxation as they are supposed to. If they do not remit moneys that they have withheld as tax, they are committing a theft and theft involves penalties.

There are a number of consequential amendments to other pieces of business legislation, such as the companies Act and the Bankruptcy Act, to accommodate the change. Senator Watson said that if the Democrats let this through it will be on our head, or something to that effect. I need to put on the record that I said to Senator Watson that probably the best way through is to excise the parts that he thinks are particularly troublesome and let these people who contacted him have a bit more time to look at the provision on penalties for directors, but in the meantime let us not hold up the rightful place of workers in the line of creditors.

This new section was announced in December, yet it is before us on the second last day of this parliamentary sitting and adequate time probably has not been given to those who feel disadvantaged by it. Nevertheless, the Democrats will support it on the understanding we have been given that the Government can answer the concerns that some bodies have about the increased penalties as they apply to directors.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Insolvency (Tax Priorities) Legislation Amendment Bill is quite an important Bill which deals with issues that a number of honourable senators have been concerned about for some time. It has received public notoriety on occasions when individual men and women, employees of companies, in financial difficulties have not been able to gain access to their wage and condition entitlements because of the priority of the Commissioner of Taxation.

PARA.TAB: Over the past three years I have had some cause to examine this in some detail. In the same way as everybody else, I started from the assumption that obviously the priority should be taken away and we should do something to protect the interests of those working men and women particularly, and subsequently of other creditors as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not in dispute.

—I want to pursue this matter because I had very severe reservations about it. I support it, but I started from the same presumption as did everybody else. My concern led me to feel that we had to proceed in a very careful fashion. The overwhelming majority of Australians running businesses are law-abiding and scrupulous citizens and, even though their companies were in difficulty, they complied with the tax laws and sent the money that had been deducted. But there were some who were either less scrupulous, or sometimes just less competent, and who failed to meet the requirements—they deducted the money and did not forward it to the Tax Office. Those people got a benefit at least in the short term. They were, in effect, financing their business with the taxpayer's money and getting a benefit over the overwhelming majority, the honest and scrupulous employers who were doing the right thing.

PARA.TAB: I had some reservations, and I had to be persuaded. My reluctance is not unique; a number of other people who looked at it came to the same view. I mention it to say that that is why it is not the straightforward measure people might first have envisaged, where we would simply take away the priority. There is a need to look at that in the proper context of the way in which these issues can be dealt with. I appreciate that in the consideration of the abolition of priority, the fundamental issue of the Bill, there is now agreement in this Senate. I was not seeking to reopen that question. I traversed it only to give a bit of background for discussion of the other matters in this legislation which are designed to make this provision effective without in any way undermining the other reasonable priorities of the tax and corporations legislation, and the way in which the consequences of these measures should be dealt with.

Senator Watson raised some concerns about the legislation and the process. If I have the opportunity, I will respond to him on the process, but the substantial thing I want to deal with is the legislation itself. Let me deal with that and, if I have time at the end, I will deal with the process.

The first concern Senator Watson raised related to the new recovery procedure and the estimate, and the fact that the estimate is not reviewable under ADJR. My advice and understanding—and I am no longer involved in the day-to-day handling of this in the way I was previously—is that the person who is in receipt of an estimate has an opportunity to declare by statutory declaration what the actual deduction was, and the commissioner will accept the amount in the declaration as being the actual deduction. So the individual has that initial opportunity to determine the amount, and that will be accepted.

Given that absolute right, the case for ADJR review seems to me to fall over although I am, in the normal course of events, one who is a supporter of the administrative review processes—the Commonwealth's administrative law reforms of the last decade or so. That is the first thing I want to set down. It is possible to run all sorts of hares on this matter, but it seems to me that there is an opportunity for individuals adequately to protect their position.

We then have a concern about the circumstance in which directors might be penalised. While an individual director may have a proper concern about process, that individual may be unable to convince other directors to act properly and, therefore, the decision would go against that one individual. This is a concern arising under proposed new division 9 where there are unremitted deductions. The liability could arise under subdivision B for the actual deduction, subdivision C for an estimate of the actual deduction or subdivision D for contravention of a payment agreement.

I am advised that each subdivision contains a provision which clarifies what defences are available to a director in recovery proceedings. For example, in respect of liability for the actual deduction under subdivision B, proposed new section 222AOJ provides that it will be a defence if it can be proved that the person did not take part in the management of the company at any time when the person was a director and the directors were under an obligation to comply. The provisions would prevent the liability arising.

Further, it will also be a defence if it can be proved that the person took all reasonable steps. In other words, that he or she did the right thing to ensure the directors complied with the provisions preventing the liability from arising. I am advised that these defences are in line with the defences available to directors under the corporations law. On the face of it, it seems reasonable that those defences should be available. That being the case, the position of directors—who, in the minority, may be seeking to persuade their co-directors to act properly—is protected.

Senator Watson raised a concern about whether there should have been an amendment to section 221Q which allows the commissioner to apply an amount equal to the deductions made in satisfaction of any tax payable by the employee in the same manner as if a group certificate in respect of the deductions had been received. It seems logical—and it has been confirmed in discussions with the officers this morning—that the provisions in the Bill will not affect the operation of section 221Q. The credit currently allowed in section 221Q is employee specific; the estimate provisions are concerned with total deductions made and not remitted in respect of all employees. The current circumstance will prevail.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's the problem. You don't know the amount to credit.

—I do not want to enter into a debate with Senator Watson across the chamber, and I am sure the Acting Deputy President, Senator Crichton-Browne, would not allow us to do so for long, but I do not see why Senator Watson thinks this amendment will create a problem for section 221Q. There is no information now available to the commissioner that will not be available after the passage of this legislation. It may be that the manner by which we seek to recover money is different, but the information that we have now on deductions will be unaffected by this amendment.
—You will miss out under an ambit claim by the commissioner because you will have no method of allocating that back to the group tax of the employee.
—It seems that Senator Watson has an extraordinarily convoluted concern.
—The purpose of the Bill is to assist employees.

—Exactly. In terms of their tax, employees will be in exactly the same situation they are in now, and in terms of all their other entitlements from their employer they will benefit. I do not want to see the Senate delaying the passage of this legislation so that individuals who may be adversely affected by the current legislation do not have the benefits of these amendments.
—It is a couple of months.

—It is only a couple of months to us, but it is the whole time in terms of the individuals who will be caught up. On almost every measure that comes into this Parliament, one could argue that there is a case for acting earlier. It is important that we take due care in the determination of any action we take. I accept that it is important in the process of the passage of the legislation that we do the same. But in this situation we are fairly well placed.

PARA.TAB: I was in my office listening to Senator Watson through the house monitoring service—I was not able to be in the chamber—but I did not pick up all the points he made relating to the concern expressed by what I understand to be a subcommittee of the Victorian Law Society concerning directors as guarantors and some other matters. It makes a change to deal with such complex nomenclature in an Act other than the tax Act. It shows that this complexity also arises in other circumstances, probably driven by the same requirement, which is to set legislation to cope with complex arrangements in a complex modern society.

I am advised that proposed section 588FGA is needed to deal with what are acknowledged to be very rare cases because normally there could not be proved any awareness by the commissioner of the insolvency at the time of the payment. The main role of this provision is as a deterrent to directors from running a company while they are insolvent. We are concerned to maintain that deterrent. Therefore, it is our view that that concern—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not maintaining anything; you are adding to an already adequate provision in corporation law. That is the point.

—We are making this consistent with them. It is true that some concern is being expressed. I do not want to pose as an authority in this area, any more than I am sure does Senator Watson. I can only proceed on the basis of the best advice available.
—That's why we need a committee for further evaluation.

—I am always impressed by Senator Watson's great faith in the Senate committee system. I have seen it do some wonderful things, but its capacity to resolve all problems is quite easily disproved by anybody who looks at some of the Bills passed by this Parliament and some of the amendments made by it.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure both Senator Watson and Senator Kernot are aware of what I am talking about. I do not deny in the slightest that some Bills—some of which I have discussed with Senator Watson and Senator Kernot—have been improved by the consideration of a committee, there is no argument about that. We have had a very limited opportunity to consider the Insolvency (Tax Priorities) Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. We would welcome the opportunity to consider this Bill in detail as it contains a large number of novel concepts and several controversial proposals over and above (and possible inconsistent with) the Government's original public statement to the effect that Crown priorities were finally to be abolished after 30 June 1993.

Regrettably, we have not had time to embark upon a consideration of the provisions proposed in respect of the accelerated and more efficient collection of relevant remittances, although we observe in passing that the Taxation Commissioner's long-standing practice of equating tax instalment deductions etc with trust monies has still not been recognised in the legislation. In other words, the employers are still to be allowed to use monies notionally deducted from the wages of employees for a period of time until obliged to remit monies calculated by reference to the remuneration of employees etc to the Commissioner.

It seems that the Bill is inclined in many ways to treat tax instalment deductions etc as if they were traceable trust monies, when such a treatment effectively accords the Commissioner a significant advantage over ordinary unsecured creditors of an insolvent company or individual.

Of additional concern is the fact that the recent amendments to the Corporation Law effected by the 1982 Corporate Law Reform Bill were exposed for a considerable period of time for public comment. The Law Council commented upon that Bill in considerable detail and the Insolvency Committee of the Business Law Section of the Council spent considerable time on the amendments introduced by that Bill in respect of insolvency matters.

Now, however, the Corporations Law is apparently to be further amended in significant aspects as a result of an initiative which seems to come from the Taxation Commissioner rather than from those responsible for the direction of Corporations Law in this country. This, in itself, should be a very good reason why further time should be afforded for public comment on the present Bill. There is no reason why the relevant provisions of the present Bill abolishing the Commissioner's priorities cannot proceed and come into operation on 1 July 1993, with all other provisions being held over for proper public input.
We have had time to consider only three particular examples of potential difficulties with the present Bill.

The proposed section 588FGA of the Corporations Law will oblige directors to indemnify the Commissioner of Taxation if certain payments by companies in respect of liabilities under the remittance provisions are set aside as preferences by a liquidator. The recently enacted provisions of the Corporations Law dealing with insolvent trading should be sufficient to protect the Commissioner and the fact that the Commissioner seeks the inclusion of an extra provision dealing only with amounts payable to him suggests that he is not really prepared to see the Government's announcement about the abolition of priorities brought into full and proper effect.

It may be that the Corporations Law could include a definition such as that contained in the proposed section 588F, although the deeming of a liability to effect a remittance of tax instalment deductions etc to be a debt does not really seem necessary.

Although directors of insolvent companies seem not to be very popular these days, they nonetheless have rights and obligations which have been carefully addressed in the recent amendments to the Corporations Law. There seems to be a further, possible unwarranted incursion upon those rights by this particular proposed amendment.

The proposed section 443BA of the Corporations Law is of particular concern having regard to the great amount of careful debate that has accompanied the introduction to the Corporations Law of the novel provisions relating to "administration" of insolvent companies. This particular proposed amendment to the Corporations Law seems at the least, ill-considered! The proposed section threatens jobs! The proposed provision would render an administrator immediately personally liable for tax instalment deductions if he were to make payment of wages to employees on the day of his appointment. Surely, administrators will be encouraged by this proposed provision to terminate employment contracts for fear of personal liability to the Commissioner of Taxation!

Amendments to section 122(4) of the Bankruptcy Act 1966 are contemplated in the Bill but a complaint made by the Law Institute of Victoria many years ago in respect of the Crown Debts (Priority) Bill—which became the Crown Debts (Priority) Act 1981—has not been addressed. Sub-section 122(4)(b) deems a payment of tax to be made for valuable consideration (with which proposition one cannot quarrel); but it also deems a payment of tax to have been made "in the ordinary course of business". The existence of this latter deeming provision accords to the Commissioner of Taxation an unfair advantage over ordinary unsecured creditors.

We would also observe, although the opportunity to consider this particular concept has been woefully insufficient, that proposed section 222APE of the Income Tax Assessment Act affording as it does only 14 days grace to company directors, would appear to be draconian.
