SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —May I say at the outset that it is wonderful to see so many young Australians in the galleries here today looking at the proceedings of the Senate from on high. I assure all of those people that it is not unusual for the Senate to look relatively unoccupied; senators from all parties are busily working away in their offices for the betterment of the nation so that all those young people grow up in a better Australia.
—And committee work.

—They are also busy with committee work, as Senator Sherry says. We are here today to deal with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill 1993. The Great Barrier Reef is a great part of world environmental heritage and a very important asset for Australia. I am sure that those in the gallery will be interested to know that this Bill seeks to ensure that the marine park authority will gain an additional source of revenue to ensure that the management of that park benefits all those who go to the Great Barrier Reef and are able to enjoy the natural beauty and some of the artificial infrastructure built up around the park.

PARA.TAB: The tourism potential of the Great Barrier Reef is of course well known. The increase in tourism numbers to that part of the world, to enjoy the Great Barrier Reef and the other natural beauties of northern Queensland, is well understood. We are told that tourism around the Great Barrier Reef itself is worth in the vicinity of $1.4 billion each and every year. It is rapidly expanding and we all expect it to expand even more rapidly with the opening up through deregulation of national and international air services and with increasing tourism infrastructure in that region.

These pressures make it much more important that these very fragile natural assets—both the wet tropics and the Great Barrier Reef region which is the subject of this Bill—be managed effectively. We need to ensure not only that this natural asset is protected but also that Australian citizens and people from other nations are able to enjoy this facility without damaging its very important natural beauty or the natural habitat. Speaking from the point of view of someone who has spent quite a lot of time sailing around the coastal waters of Australia, I guess that many people—particularly those who go to sea, whether in small boats or larger ships—would see the Great Barrier Reef not only as a natural asset but also as something to be avoided if they are travelling around in a ship.

The general objective of this Bill is to raise a $1 per day per person charge. It is to be collected through the many tourist operators in this region. That money will go to the authority essentially for management purposes. The Opposition will be supporting this Bill, although we do have some reservations which were put by shadow Minister for the environment in the other place. Specifically, we do not want to see a diminution of the general funding that goes to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority—affectionately known as GBRMPA—because the research operations of the authority, as well as the management operations, are very important. As I have said, we have increasing pressure on the natural environment in the Great Barrier Reef region and therefore more money will need to go into its management.

Although we support the user-pays principle, and the way that people who go to see the reef will be required to make a contribution to its management and ongoing research, we do not want to see the amount of funding which goes into the management of this park—be it through GBRMPA or other authorities—diluted. As pressure increases, the demand for research on management of the park and on how to balance the recreational needs with the environmental needs will also increase.

The Opposition is also concerned to see that the charges are levied on people in a fair and equitable manner. We have some reservations about the fact that the charge is being collected only through tourist operators. However, we are cognisant of the fact that this is probably the most effective way of collecting these charges. Also, given our past experience with government imposed levies and charges, it would not be unreasonable to expect that this charge will creep up once it is introduced.

I am sure that all honourable senators and honourable members of this Parliament will be keen to ensure that increases through this new form of taxation or levy are kept under scrutiny. That is not to say that the charge should not go up in the future; there may be good reasons for it to be increased. However, as people representing the citizens of Australia, we need to keep a watch on that.

I have already mentioned the fact that recreational users who come onto the reef or into that region other than through tourist operators will not be subject to the charge. In that respect, the burden of the management of the park does not fall equitably on all of its users. But, of course, it would be hard to achieve the collection of the charge in any other way.

At present the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority receives annually in the order of $14 million from the Federal Government, $3 million from the Queensland Government and a further $3 million from its own commercial operations. Having spoken to the people at the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority during a couple of visits to that region in my role as a member of the Senate Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts—of which I know that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, are a very active and diligent member—I am aware that that authority is under enormous stress to carry out its functions with the fiscal restraint which is being imposed on all Federal Government activities by its gross economic mismanagement. To the extent that this user-pays fee collection process which this Bill encompasses will help relieve that situation,

SPEECH.PARA: it has our full support. On behalf of the Opposition, I commend these Bills to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats also support the passage of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park (Environmental Management Charge—General) Bill 1993, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park (Environmental Management Charge—Excise) Bill 1993 and the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Amendment Bill 1993. We believe that these Bills will add significantly to the proper management of the tourist impact on the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. We note that the Great Barrier Reef has been made a World Heritage area. However, it is also an area in which a range of commercial activities continue to function extremely profitably.

PARA.TAB: It is important for people to understand that the declaration of an area as a World Heritage does not necessarily mean the curtailment of economic activities. As Senator Campbell has just pointed out, when one looks at the $1 billion to $1.6 billion of income which comes from tourism on the Great Barrier Reef, one sees that the amount raised under this levy scheme of just over $1m is 0.1 per cent of the total revenue raised through tourism on the reef. It is a very small amount. One must also observe that the return on the investment is extremely large.

I just wanted to make the point that here we have a World Heritage area which is being used in a commercial way, responsibly without serious damage. This charge will add to the reef's better management. For those who look at the declaration of other areas with certain circumspection because they are concerned that it might interfere with commercial activities, I invite them to look at the Great Barrier Reef and see that, in that case, not only is the commercial use of a World Heritage area consistent with that declaration but also that the commercialisation of those natural assets often leads to an extremely profitable venture.

We are in favour of the passage of these related Bills. We believe that the introduction of a charge on commercial operators is an example of ecologically sustainable development at work on the Great Barrier Reef. It is a mechanism by which the current users of the reef can be made to pick up some of the cost of damage and potential damage to the reef. This will ensure that the reef will be there for the enjoyment of further generations and also for the protection of the indigenous species. We must not forget that ecologically sustainable development does not mean only the protection of species and ecologies for the enjoyment of future generations of humans; it also means the protection and preservation in the long term for their own sake.

The park has been recognised internationally not only for its World Heritage values but also for the very successful balance of environmental and economic concerns which have been institutionalised in the management of the park. The establishment of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority back in 1976 allowed a single agency to research and manage the impacts of tourism, fishing, mariculture, agriculture, human settlements, coastal development and other activities in the marine park.

I understand that the charge will be administered by the marine park authority. Although the charge will be passed on to the consumer of the commercial service, the cost per person will essentially be insignificant. The charge will have no negative social equity effects. However, it will raise between $1.25 million and $1.5 million per year to be spent on research, education, information and better protection of the park.

I interpolate at this point that the Democrats are concerned that charges such as this should be levied in a socially equitable way and that the imposition of a charge should not be used as a mechanism by which progressively government is relieved of the responsibility of looking after the park. We would be very concerned that the charge not be progressively raised and the charge become a mechanism for revenue rather than a mechanism of addressing—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a false hope.

—I think it is important to inject that note into these issues precisely for that reason—to express the concern we all have, because we have seen it in so many other ways in which quite modest charges have been introduced, and then it has progressively become a mechanism by which government is relieved of its important responsibilities. The charge is extremely small when compared with a total amount—as I have said, perhaps something of the order of $1 billion to $1.6 billion. So the charge represents something of the order of 0.1 per cent of the gross income from tourism on the reef. We are satisfied that the amount raised will significantly boost the revenue available to the authority.

PARA.TAB: I am also pleased to note that the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) stated in her second reading speech that the introduction of the charge will not lead to a modification of current arrangements for funding the authority through Budget appropriations—I stress that again—but is specifically aimed at offsetting the costs of increasing commercial use of the park. The charge is related to the number of passengers on commercial tourist boats using the park on a daily basis. The great majority of park visitors take advantage of commercial operators to view the park's attractions. A charge is certainly a rational way of spreading the costs as the revenue raised would increase or decrease according to the number of tourists visiting the park. Therefore, the charge is directly related to the impact of humans on the park.

The obvious omission, and this has been referred to by Senator Campbell, is the relatively small group of tourists who visit the reef on a private non-commercial basis on non-commercial boats. These people may have—and this is only a hypothetical situation—a greater impact on the reef because they are not exposed to the interpretive material in relation to the values of the park and the responsibilities of park users provided by the commercial operators or by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. These people can, in one way, be regarded as free-riders or, in another sense, as romantic travellers operating outside the strictures of regulation. However one views them, there is no way of denying that they will receive a benefit for which others will be obliged to pay when these charges come into operation. I am therefore in support of a proposal to introduce charges on boat owners who use their personal boats to view the park. All private boat owners would pay a fee to the marine park authority when they register their presence in the park. We believe that this would be relatively easy to capture in some suitable way.

The other issue I want to raise is recreational fishing within the park. Recreational fishing has a significant impact on the fisheries resource within the park. A survey undertaken in 1991 by Dr Tor Hundloe and Mr Russell Blamey of Griffith University estimated that in 1990 between 3.5 million and 4.3 million kilograms of fish were caught by recreational fishers on the reef, compared with an estimated commercial catch of 4 million kilograms. In other words, the recreational fishers caught the same weight of fish as their commercial counterparts.

Another significant finding of the survey was that the weight of fish—this is, the weight of the individual fish caught—had fallen by an estimated 40 per cent since similar estimations were made with respect to the 1980 catch. The survey also found that the average size of fish caught in reef waters off Mackay was 1.4 kilograms, a fall of 39 per cent from the average reported in a survey of 1980. In waters off Townsville, the average size had fallen by 19 per cent. Clearly, the increase in recreational fishing in the reef is having a significant impact on fish stocks.

I understand that the Deputy Premier of Queensland, Mr Tom Burns, and the State Minister for Primary Industries, Mr Edmund Casey, have called an inquiry into recreational fishing in Queensland. I hope that this will lead to better management of recreational fishing along the entire Queensland coastline and within inland waters. I would urge the New South Wales and Victorian governments to undertake a similar inquiry, as recreational fishing is heaviest along the east coast of Australia.

Senators would be aware that the management of fisheries under Commonwealth control is currently being reviewed by the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. It is certainly true that the human impact on fish stocks throughout Australia, both inland and off the coasts, has been extremely damaging, and fisheries generally are not being managed in a sustainable way. In passing, I point out that increasing populations of humans, if they are going to enjoy access to fish, will further impact on the fish stocks of this country.

I note that in tandem with the Queensland inquiry the Commonwealth is developing a national policy on recreational fishing. A draft discussion paper was released in December last year. The paper includes a number of revenue raising measures, such as direct contributions by the Commonwealth, the wholesale fishing gear levy and the introduction of State or Territory fees by way of licences, fees or tags on recreational fishers.

The Democrats support, in principle, options to raise revenue to regulate recreational fishing, given its significant impact on the Australian fish stock. The bottom line in any recreational pursuit is that an activity must not threaten a species with extension or impede the recovery of a threatened species. However, the Democrats are mindful of the social implications of such measures, given that recreational fishing is such an important leisure activity. Any options will therefore be considered within a framework that integrates social and environmental interests.

In conclusion, the Democrats fully support this legislation and will not be seeking any amendments to it. The charge will help to raise revenue for research and enhance management of human impact on the reef. It is not designed as an entry fee but simply as a levy on commercial operators so that they can contribute to the maintenance of a World Heritage area in which the World Heritage values of the reef must be protected.

I hope that the other policy options discussed in this speech will be pursued with vigour by the relevant authorities in order to ensure that the reef is protected for the enjoyment and inspiration of all current and future generations and also, I stress, because of the intrinsic value of the reef, and the value of the species of flora and fauna which inhabit that reef.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my privilege today to make a very brief contribution to this debate in support of the Great Barrier Reef legislation and in support of the very fine speech which my colleague Senator Campbell gave in introducing the Opposition's case. The legislation introduces a user-pays principle to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park and, together with the regulations that will be tabled subsequently, it will enable the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority to levy tourist operators on the basis of the number of tourists who use their facilities.

PARA.TAB: Anything to do with the Barrier Reef is of very great interest to all Australians, including to all parliamentarians. It is something that I take a very great interest in because the area of Queensland in which I operate in a parliamentary sense—from the Bundaberg region right through to the Torres Strait—encompasses the Barrier Reef. So I am particularly pleased to be able to make a contribution about a natural asset that is so vital to the people I principally represent.

There is no doubt that the Barrier Reef is one of the, if not the, greatest treasures and greatest tourist attractions in the world. It is obviously something that should be protected sensibly. However, at the same time we should not close it off to everybody except a few privileged people, as quite often happens in other areas of our natural environment.

I am pleased to see that transit operators will be exempt from the Bill. This is specifically important to the people of Townsville and Magnetic Island, because ferries run between those two destinations as a conveyance of passengers other than tourists. I would object very greatly if that ferry service were to be included in this Bill because it would mean a quite substantial increase in the price of the tickets.
For the first time, tourist operators will be permitted to transfer their permits. This will mean that they will be able to sell their permits to other operators as they go along.

As my colleague Senator Campbell has said, we do not oppose the legislation. But I am very disappointed with the way this Government has gone about introducing this tax. It presented the tax to the industry as a fait accompli. There was not a great deal of consultation. People in the industry were told that they were going to have it and that they might as well try to sort out the best deal that they could for the industry, knowing it would be coming in.

The then Queensland Environment and Heritage Minister, Mr Comben, was carpeted by the Labor Premier of Queensland when Mr Comben went along with the Commonwealth plan. Mr Goss called the proposal `half-baked', and then pledged to oppose it. I do not know where he is now. I suspect he is all over the place, as he usually is. At that stage, he did say that he would oppose it. As I said, the main reason why the industry accepted the tax was that it knew it was coming and the Government was willing to trade off some benefits for operators in relation to the permits.

The industry is concerned that it is the thin edge of the wedge: $1 today, $5 tomorrow. That is something that this Parliament will have to look at very closely. In her second reading speech, the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) said that the regulations will specify that the charge will be only $1 per day per tourist. How this will be incorporated into regulations will be very interesting. It is something that we will watch very closely, as the tourist operators and many other people, including myself, have very real fears that this will not be so easy.

The tourist operators have asked me how the Government will incorporate that fee. A tourist may take a launch over to, say, Green Island; then, after arriving, stay in a hotel; buy some meals; play some water sports; take an underwater submarine, a submersible, and go out to a reef platform. Will the Government add this dollar on every occasion that the tourist buys a ticket for something? If not, how will the Government incorporate it? How will it work in that way? It is something that the Government will have some difficulty with. Certainly, the industry is very concerned about it, and I await with interest the regulations.

As we all know, the Barrier Reef has been a very popular destination with Japanese and American tourists and, increasingly, European tourists; also, a great number of backpackers in the north visit that destination. They are attracted to the north because of the Barrier Reef. I suppose I should declare an interest in speaking on this Bill. It involves the Barrier Reef and I have a very small interest in a backpacking establishment in North Queensland. I suppose by supporting this Bill I am assisting my business in some way. It is very important to ensure that that reef is available to tourists in all areas. Whilst the backpackers spend only about $10 a night on accommodation, they are quite lavish when it comes to spending money on reef trips and dives on the reef. So they are a very important asset.

One of the difficulties with the tourist industry at the moment is the huge number of taxes that are imposed upon it by the Federal Labor Government and the Queensland Labor Government. Some studies have been done which estimate that government taxes now amount to about 40 per cent of the total revenue in the tourism industry.

I cannot understand why boats plying the barrier reef currently pay a fuel tax of 26c—and in some cases more—per litre. Madam Acting Deputy President, you will remember that the fuel tax was originally imposed to help build roads. Even though most of the revenue from the fuel tax is ripped off by this Government and used as general revenue, 7c or 8c of that tax supposedly goes towards the upkeep of roads.

Tourist boat operators pay the fuel tax even though I have never, in my lifetime, seen any of those reef catamarans running down the main street of Townsville or Cairns or travelling the Bruce Highway. These operators still pay a fuel tax supposedly to assist in the upkeep of roads. I think it is iniquitous that tourist operators are required to pay that tax when they get nothing back for it. It was my hope that the amount these operators paid in fuel tax could be used for research and maintenance of the reef rather than a new tax being imposed. I note that in the fishing industry similar boats that ply the same waters do not pay a fuel tax, and yet these tourist operators do.

In addition to the reef tax, reef tourism operators are hit heavily by other taxes and charges: such as, sales tax, payroll tax, petrol tax, the training guarantee levy, a navigation levy, an oil pollution levy, registration and permit fees, and stamp duty. It has been suggested in some studies that government taxes and charges amount to 40 per cent of total revenue for tourist operators and this is before any of their expenses are paid.

We have seen floated in the last couple of days the horrendous suggestion of a new $30 per head arrival tax. This tax will be on top of the $20 per head departure tax which has very recently been doubled by this Government. It is suggested that this new arrival tax of $30 per head would raise $147 million a year based on the figure of almost five million people arriving in Australia. This will be just another tax on tourism and something which could adversely affect the industry in Cairns and far North Queensland.

A couple of tourist operators were caught out because they were agents for the Labor Party. There was the very notable incident where a so-called independent tourist seminar was organised and we found out that it was actually being operated and paid for by a staffer of a Labor Party Minister. That staffer was using a different name, although it sounded a bit like his own name.

There was a small group of tourism operators in the employ of ALP who, before the last election, tried to raise some fears about the impact of the GST on the tourism industry. I was quite convinced, and I think most sensible tourism operators were convinced, that there would be no adverse impact on the tourist industry because of benefits that would have flowed from the proposal. This small group of operators, egged on by the ALP, made a bit of noise and had a few headlines on this subject. They are not concerned now about all the other taxes being imposed on the tourism industry. I wonder why we do not now hear their voices in opposition to the reef tax and arrival tax when they were so vocal about this matter before the election.

If this $30 per head arrival tax were to be introduced it would be an enormous impost on the industry. It is something that could cripple the tourist industry, which is one of Australia's export earners. I note in today's Financial Review that the Chief Executive of the Australian Tourism Industry Association, Mr O'Cleary, said:

SPEECH.PARA: If the proposal were put up, the whole tourism industry would be up in arms . . . Such abhorrent suggestion doesn't bear thinking about.

I certainly hope the Government, in its desperate attempt to raise money from anywhere and everywhere, does not again target tourism to try to get out of the financial mess into which it has got itself. The pious comments made before the election about the effect of the GST on the tourism industry will be shown to be just more of the hypocrisy of the Labor Party if the Government even looks at getting money from an arrival tax on Australian tourists.

PARA.TAB: I support the legislation. I will certainly be joining other members of the Liberal and National parties in monitoring the situation and the regulations as they come through. We will do so to ensure that the tax which is being introduced now is not the thin end of the wedge; that it stops where it says it will; and that it is not used by this Government as a crutch to enable it to stop funding the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. Rather than the Government using Consolidated Revenue to fund what is a very important research and maintenance agency which protects one of Australia's greatest assets, funding in the future should be by way of an increase in the tax.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also will be supporting the passage of this package of legislation, which is designed to introduce a charge on certain users of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park to assist with research into the impacts of various activities on the reef system. I understand that this legislation is the end product of remarkable community cooperation by and consultation with all the different interest groups connected with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. The concern for environmental management has led to agreement from all parties that charges will be paid by commercial operators on the basis of a dollar per day per person, which will raise approximately $1 million a year.

PARA.TAB: The availability of these funds is likely to benefit research in at least two areas. Firstly, in the area of water quality it will be possible to look at the effect of both the residential and commercial run-off from the Queensland mainland. The second area is research into fishing effects, particularly bottom-trawling. There has been no comprehensive research to date in this respect. Senator Coulter mentioned the research that has been carried out on recreational fishing impacts. It is also important to carry out research into the impact of commercial fishing on fish stocks. As Senator Coulter pointed out, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park is a good example of a World Heritage area being used responsibly for commercial activity. It is also now presenting a model of cooperation of interested parties for sensitive environmental management and research.

I take this opportunity to point to the need for similar schemes in other parts of Australia to assist with funding the very necessary research that is needed to ensure the continued protection of the resources that attract the many tourists in this country. The environmental impact of tourism was examined comprehensively in the report The Australian environment and tourism produced by the Senate Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts in September 1992. The introduction to that report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Pressure on the environment from tourism is increasing. It is anticipated that the number of foreign tourists could treble by the year 2000; domestic tourism, currently about eighty per cent of the market, is expected to remain vigorous. There is a need to consider carefully the ways in which the Australian environment is under threat from tourism. Unless those threats can be identified, tourism could increase the damage to the very environment that is attractive to tourists, and on which the industry in large part depends. In other words, it will kill the goose that lays the golden egg.

It should be noted, however, that the health of our environment is of value not only to the tourism industry but also to industries such as fishing and agriculture, which rely on healthy ecosystems for their survival. Therefore, continued research into the environmental impact of human activity is essential if our industries are to be sustainable. So it is only right that those industries that benefit from Australia's beautiful and healthy environment should contribute to research into these issues. I trust that the Government will consider these issues as part of its plans to implement the recommendations of the final report on ecologically sustainable development.

PARA.TAB: I also take this opportunity to call on the Government to initiate a similar scheme in conjunction with the Western Australian Government to ensure the continued protection of the Ningaloo Reef Marine Park. This park, which is considered by many ecologists to be as important as the Great Barrier Reef, is unique in that it is so close to the coastline. While this provides tourists with the opportunity to walk or swim to the reef in some places, it also poses a threat to the very delicate ecosystem of the reef. All developments in the area need to be considered very carefully in that context. Therefore, the Federal Government's intervention through legislative protection, together with a funded research scheme similar to that being proposed today, is essential for its long-term protection.

I was delighted to hear Senator Campbell's support for the responsible and sensitive environmental management of the Great Barrier Reef and hope he will maintain this stance to protect the Ningaloo Reef in our mutual home State. I commend all the parties who have supported and put together this proposal. I support the Bills currently before the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. The Auditor-General's report tabled in the Senate yesterday revealed financial obligations in excess of $125 billion by the Federal Government, further potential obligations of $44 billion and liquid assets of only $57 billion to meet the bill. Does the Minister agree with the Auditor-General that this massive financial burden can only be met through increased taxes, privatisation or reduced expenditure?

—It needs to be appreciated that the Auditor-General's report acknowledges that the Commonwealth's financial position is fundamentally sound. Whatever improvements in accounting systems and so on that might be appropriate and were recommended in the report, there is absolutely nothing in the language of that report which would remotely justify the kind of bizarre and over-the-top reaction we have seen from the Opposition, and particularly from Mr Costello in his extraordinary reference to child abuse. If that is the quality of informed and mature comment we can expect from the new Opposition in relation to these matters, God help this country in the future.

PARA.TAB: The report focuses on the outstanding obligations of the Commonwealth, but what it ignores, in all but passing, is the Government's significant asset base and, more importantly, the Commonwealth Government's capacity to fund these obligations over time through its existing revenue base.The report notes that the face value of its debt at June 1992 was 11.8 per cent of GDP. This compares favourably with the prior 10-year average of 13.2 per cent. It is also worth making the point that the Commonwealth is extremely well placed with respect to its financial obligations when compared with other OECD governments. OECD statistics show that Australia's net general government debt in 1992 represented only 16 per cent of GDP, and that is less than half that of the average for the G7 countries and below that of all the major OECD countries except Japan.

—Does the Minister representing the Treasurer agree that the dependent spouse rebate is an important tax equity measure, especially beneficial to single income households? Will the Minister therefore give an assurance that the Government does not regard the promised cashed out payment of a rebate to be directed to a dependent spouse with children as a welfare measure and therefore vulnerable to reduction or even elimination, as if its payment were a social security benefit?

There is no cause for any concern on those grounds.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. He will recall that during the election campaign Mr Keating said of investments in the pipeline:

QUESTION.PARA: There's 130,000 million dollars of investments . . . It's all about to move like a big avalanche.

Given that today's private capital expenditure figures have confirmed that private capital expenditure has continued at a depressed level for the last 15 months, following a massive fall in the preceding 2 1/2 years, when is investment about `to move like a big avalanche'?

TALK.START.PARA: —A fall in business investment was expected in the March quarter purely because of the strong December quarter result. Abstracting from the large one-off elements in the December quarter, the latest capital expenditure release does suggest that investment in plant and equipment has turned around and has grown in the last two quarters. So what Senator Short is trying to do with that question is extrapolate from a particular quarter's figures, which are not appropriate to draw the conclusions that he has drawn from them. We are very confident that the conditions have been established for a sustainable recovery, including major new investment expenditure, with the assistance, encouragement and incentive of the investment allowances that were an essential part of our campaign platform, and we fully expect that situation to be realised.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I assume from that answer that Senator Evans is not aware that, taking the last 15 months as a whole, investment has been absolutely flat and that that followed a massive fall in private investment in the preceding 2 1/2 years. What impact will the further fall in investment for the March quarter, announced today, have on next week's national accounts? In particular, does the Minister agree that the accounts could show a return to negative growth?

—I repeat, because I do not think Senator Short was listening very carefully, that although there was a large fall-off in the March quarter, 9.2 per cent under the just released capital expenditure survey measure, this did follow a very strong rise in the December quarter that was due unquestionably to large one-off factors. Overall we are very confident that there are signs that over the last two quarters investment in plant and equipment has begun to grow again after falling—it is readily acknowledged—for the previous 12 quarters, and that total business fixed investment may have bottomed. That is the assessment of the Treasury. I am not going to second guess that. I am certainly not going to make any judgments about what will or will not show up in the national accounts figures to which Senator Short refers. I am not going to pre-empt that judgment.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I ask whether the Minister noted, in the Melbourne Age, an editorial on 17 May urging:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . despite our economic difficulties, the Government should resist the temptation to reduce foreign aid in this year's Budget.
Has the Government responded to the request of the Australian Council for Overseas Aid to lift our aid from 0.36 per cent of GNP to 0.38 per cent in this coming Budget?

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly did note that editorial and personally I entirely share its sentiments. Whether we will be able to achieve not only a growth in aid but just a maintenance of the status quo is very much something that will have to be addressed in the Budget context.

PARA.TAB: The truth of the matter is, as I recall the figures, that given that forward estimates each year—the way in which they are constructed—do not necessarily fully reflect the nature of the going obligations we have in the aid budget, it would take in the order of $40 million new money in the Budget on top of forward estimates simply to stay where we are. In real terms it will take something like a $70 million injection from the Budget to stay where we are in ODA to GNP ratio terms at 0.36. It will take something like another $111 million to $112 million worth of new aid money in the Budget to start making an impact on the 0.4 medium term target that we have set ourselves as a way station en route, hopefully, to finally achieving the 0.7 international target.

I mention those figures simply to demonstrate to Senator Powell, and to those who share my very strong commitment to the continuation of Australia's aid profile, the magnitude of the task we have, given the other budgetary disciplinary pressures that are upon us this year. Certainly we will be trying—Gordon Bilney, the Minister with particular responsibility for this area, and Senator Cook will be working very hard with me—not only to maintain the position but hopefully to improve it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If the Minister, somewhat understandably, cannot commit himself here today to that incremental increase, can he tell the Senate how that still rather mean 0.4 per cent promised by 1995 might be achieved if there is no increase this year?
—With great difficulty.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Family Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. I refer to the Government's unaffordable and regressive income tax cuts, under which about 60 per cent of the women of Australia get no tax cut at all, and I ask: what advice has the Office of the Status of Women provided on the income tax cuts? What representations has the Minister made to the Prime Minister on this issue, and what has been his response? Is the Minister concerned that these tax cuts can only be paid for by massive cuts in services or by regressive indirect tax increases which will impact heavily on women?
—That matter is very clearly a question that belongs to the Treasurer, so I will seek an answer in detail for the senator and supply it to her.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the Minister then tell me why she has not approached the Prime Minister about the biggest fiscal issue of this decade, particularly as it affects women?
—I have said that I will seek an answer from the Treasurer, and I certainly will.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I am sure the Minister is aware that, because of economic, language or cultural barriers, many people have difficulty seeking legal advice on immigration matters. What help is the Federal Government giving to non-profit immigration advisory services to help such people in gaining access to advice?

—Senator Beahan has raised an issue which is of concern to people with non-English speaking backgrounds—that is, the barriers that they confront when they need advice on migration matters, particularly when they need to get it from solicitors or migration consultants. The Government realises that there is an important role for community-based advisory services in this field, particularly to overcome those problems that Senator Beahan mentions—not only economic barriers but also language and culture barriers.

PARA.TAB: At the end of 1991, Mr Hand introduced a competitive financial grants scheme, funded by the Federal Government, to assist community-based immigration advisory service organisations. Under the immigration advisory services scheme, I have now been able to make grants totalling up to $310,000 for this financial year. They have been made to non-profit organisations for the purpose of providing advice to people who have difficulty accessing advice from solicitors or migration consultants.

Four organisations based in New South Wales, Victoria, Queensland and Western Australia will receive funds under this decision. The Catholic Migrant Centre of Western Australia will receive $40,000, the South Brisbane Immigration and Community Legal Service will receive $50,000, and the Victorian and New South Wales immigration advice and rights centres will receive $125,000 and $95,000 respectively. All four of these organisations have met crucial eligibility criteria. They have had to register; they have had to provide evidence to us that they have a sound knowledge and understanding of migration law. They also must meet a very important imperative: none of them must restrict its assistance to any specific group of migrants.

We will also be reporting on accountability processes for the duration of the funding being used by those organisations. We see this is an important initiative in that a whole range of people cannot access advice in areas where they need it and where it is vital to their lives and those of their families. The Government is pleased to make this announcement.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. What explanation will the Minister give for there being two increases, each of between five and 10 per cent, on Bass Strait sea freight within a period of six months?

—I have actually answered this question twice before. But what I will do—and Senator Archer might find this very instructive reading—is provide the honourable senator with the actual statistics on the freight rates across Bass Strait over the past 10 years. What Senator Archer will see is that they have progressively fallen in real terms.

—Is the Minister for Health aware of the drug sumitriptan which is used to treat migraine? Has the drug been recommended for inclusion on the PBS schedule? When can migraine sufferers expect to receive this drug at a sensible price?

—A number of members of parliament and members of the public have raised this matter with me, which is not hard to understand, given that it is said that about one and a half million Australians suffer from migraine. So I think it is reasonable that people would be concerned.
—How many with gout?

—I do not know how many people have gout, but I am among them. If the question were about gout, this might have been a different answer. This is a pretty new drug and its manufacturer is now asking that the Government list the drug on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. While sumitriptan is certainly better than other treatments currently available for at least half our migraine sufferers, it is not so much better as to justify the extraordinary price that the manufacturer, Glaxo, is asking for it.

PARA.TAB: Advice to the Government suggests that to approve this drug would mean adding about $240 million a year to the Government's pharmaceutical bill. Given that the Government spends in total about $1.4 million on other drugs, that is an increase of more than 15 per cent for only one drug. That would be more than we spend as a nation on medical research. It would be more than the total cost of hospital services in southern Sydney. It is an extraordinary amount.

As good as this drug may be, we all have to ask ourselves whether it is fair for taxpayers to fund that exorbitant price. The manufacturers are asking to charge a price of $41.45 for two tablets. My advice from the medical profession is that many sufferers require three to four tablets an episode—and that makes this a very expensive number.

I know that the claim is always that the price is set to do two things: to recover development costs—and I think we would have to concede that they are considerable, they probably amount to hundreds of millions of dollars—and also to give some kind of stimulus or incentive to discover new and better drugs in the future. The problem is that our calculations suggest that if Glaxo maintains the price it is asking the Government for—which is pretty similar to the world price it has set for this drug; a price it is trying to get all world governments to cop, particularly those in the OECD—the company will get between $15 and $20 billion a year, every single year. I would say that that is some kind of stimulus. It is not the kind of stimulus that the Government would be prepared to pay.

While the company, naturally enough, claims that $240 million is grossly overestimating the cost to us, if one looks at the record for drug after drug, one sees that time after time the Government's estimates in this respect have been pretty accurate. If one looks at simvastatin, the cholesterol drug, and cyclosporin, one realises that our estimates have come in very close to cost. Those drugs are the most recent of the new, expensive drugs. I do not think $240 million is going to be far out. It is an awful lot of money. It is something that Australians are going to have to consider.

In 1991-92, Glaxo received a subsidy of around $90 million from our scheme. We have to ask ourselves as a nation whether we are prepared to pay the exorbitant price that this multinational drug company is asking us for, or whether we stand on some sort of principle and say that perhaps there are better ways to spend a vast sum of money like that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Why did Senator Evans, as the responsible Minister, not refer to the Australian Federal Police the serious allegations against his department of tampering with documents relating to the alleged irregularities into the inquiry against the former Ambassador to Chile? As tampering with documents is an offence under the Crimes Act which can carry a penalty of seven years imprisonment, why did the Minister leave it to the former Ambassador to report it to the AFP and not do it himself?

—I have only just become aware of these allegations from the former Ambassador. They are part of a long series of allegations about alleged departmental mismanagement of the particularly disciplinary action which is being pursued against him. That is a matter of ongoing—

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Well Senator Hill might do so with his well-known judgment, but it has been conspicuously astray in so many other respects. This has been handled completely at arms length from me through departmental disciplinary procedures and through some associated court action, or threatened court action. I have not seen any ground so far for any intervention on my part being justified. I will have a further look at it in the light of Senator Knowles's question, but I would not have thought it would have been appropriate for me to take any action at all in this respect.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Has the Minister in fact seen the documents that have been tampered with and quite clearly altered, and if not why not? Could the Minister inform the Senate as to what other irregularities in his department, associated with this investigation, have not been followed up? I would have thought that the Minister would have been advised of such a serious thing that can attach a penalty of seven years' imprisonment. When was he advised?

—All I have seen in this respect, as I recall, is a letter that came in during the last week or so from the former Ambassador to Chile making allegations of this kind. It is one of a long series of letters that I have received from the Ambassador over a long period of time. The view that I have taken about the conduct of this particular investigation and the disciplinary matter that is proceeding is that it is much better for the whole thing to be dealt with at absolute arms length from the Minister, and that is the way that I have tackled it all along. These are complicated disciplinary proceedings against a former Ambassador for which there is ample disciplinary machinery available. None of it either requires or, in my view, justifies the intervention of the Minister. That is the view that I propose to continue to take on this matter.
—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. Are the claims that the Terrell report shows that the aviation standards have fallen accurate?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad to get that question. I was hoping I would get one from the Opposition this afternoon; unfortunately, it has not followed up the matter. One of the things that I, as someone who has a very serious interest in air safety, get very annoyed about—and I think rightly so—is when reports are made that are not accurate and when honourable senators, particularly, get up, as one did yesterday, and claim that there is a report around the place that shows that the situation is, in fact, near disastrous in terms of safety. This is not the case.

PARA.TAB: Senator Bishop should pay close attention to this. It has been reported that the airlines expressed concerns over the CAA's safety regulation division. They did. What was not reported—and I hope it is now reported; and I did tell the Senate about this yesterday—is that after these concerns were raised, and after the airlines met with the CAA to discuss these concerns, as a direct consequence of those meetings, the Australian Aviation Industry Association, which is the peak major airlines body in Australia, has six representatives on the working party that is now addressing the Terrell report. The CAA staff unions also have six representatives, as I mentioned yesterday, and the working groups have access to all material available to management, including the annexes to the Terrell report.

I am aware of today's editorial in the Canberra Times, which I have read carefully and which contains a couple of patently incorrect assertions. The first was that I attempted to `suppress' the appendices of the report. Senator Evans correctly put the position on this matter. The record shows that, having an inch-thick wad of documents, all of which automatically attracted privilege, dumped in the Senate yesterday, all I sought time to do was to examine them to see whether there were any matters of concern, particularly in the case of individuals who might have been named, that should not attract privilege. I did that. I read the papers, and I had no objection to what was contained in them. As the Whip will report, through the Government Whip I advised the Opposition that I had no concerns, and the papers were all tabled as a result of what I said yesterday.

The article then said that the CAA has not demonstrated that any of these changes have produced `net economic benefits'. To talk about economics and not safety, which is the bottom line as far as I am concerned, is a nonsense. The Senate was advised that the CAA has already passed on to airlines savings of $96 million in the current financial year, and they are very appreciative of it; that it has lowered its charges to the airline industry by almost $100 million this financial year; and that it anticipates there will be further savings on top of that in excess of $60 million in the coming financial year.

The Government's position is that the bottom line is safety. To get to the truth of the matter, I could do no more than refer to an interview carried on AM this morning with Alan Terrell himself. In terms of whether safety standards have fallen as far as he is concerned in his report, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: I do not think there is anything `in the regular public transport sector or the regional operators sector' which would indicate that there is any cause for alarm at all, no.
I conclude by saying this: I made reference—

TALK.START.PARA: —What did he say about general aviation?

—Senator Tambling should ask that as a supplementary. If he does so, I will answer it. I will say this, and it is very important: I mentioned yesterday that there was one document that Senator Bishop did not table, and that was the reply of the chairman of the CAA board to Captain Terrell's letter. It is a matter for the chairman of the board, but I want to say this publicly: I believe that he has no choice but to make that letter available. It is his decision. He has no choice but to make it available as a result of the Opposition dumping the other stuff here in the Senate yesterday. What the press gallery and those opposite might like to do is read the transcript of what Alan Terrell said this morning and the chairman's report.
—Order! The time has expired.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. I remind the Minister of three warnings from independent groups in the past two years on the need for action in respect of air safety. The first warning by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation in early 1991, following eight `near misses' at Sydney airport, said the airport was a `near collision waiting to happen'. The second warning, again by the bureau less than six months later, involved a call for a review of the simultaneous use of runways at Sydney airport. The third warning by the Aviation Safety Regulation Forum last August urged the Civil Aviation Authority to get back to its primary role of protecting air safety standards. I ask the Minister: firstly, why has it taken a fourth warning, with the tabling of the Terrell report by the Opposition yesterday, for him to take notice of the threats to public safety and finally chair a meeting on the issue; and, secondly, why has he been so unwilling to meet his ministerial responsibilities in yet another area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that I have been asked this question.
—Oh, you are not really!

—Yes, I am really. Not only can I attest to those warnings, I can provide Senator Bishop with another 50, 60 or 70 concerns about air safety in Australia. Those concerns are rightly and consistently made. The CAA is constantly reviewing its operations in cooperation with the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation. In fact, we currently have in this country an expert in air space management from Canada. This person has been brought to Australia by the CAA to look at its air space proposals. I would just reiterate—and I am pleased and give AM credit for actually putting this on the record in its introduction this morning—that the reason we are debating this at all is that the Terrell report, as I said yesterday, was in fact commissioned by the CAA board itself. The CAA board initiated this matter.

PARA.TAB: The utterances of Senator Bishop about why I have just suddenly decided to chair this meeting are nonsense, too. I am happy to give her a copy of the letter. As I told the Senate yesterday, I have had a number of direct personal meetings with representatives of the aircraft engineers. I have had a meeting with them in company with Alan Terrell. I told the Senate this yesterday—have a look at the Hansard. I wrote to the engineers last week before any of this happened—and I will give those opposite a copy of the letter—proposing, as a result of several weeks of meetings, that I would chair a round table meeting. One of the reasons I wanted that round table meeting was to have all of the parties in the same room at the same time. Instead of getting second and third hand reports from unions about what management thinks or from management about what unions think, I have found it a very useful and instructive exercise over the years to put everybody together in the room. I have suggested doing that on this occasion—and it will be done.

Unfortunately, before I got any response to that letter from the engineers, they took strike action which, as I said yesterday, I am glad they have now lifted because I have reiterated that proposal to them. Also, I have laid out the timetable. Why does Senator Bishop not read what Captain Terrell said this morning? It might be instructive for her if she did. I will read what he said about this. Alan Terrell said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . I didn't suggest it—
and he is talking about safety standards—
had got down to below or even close to the normal recognised minimum.
SHOVELAND:But you did pose the question that how much had safety standards been eroded, didn't you?
To which he replied:
Yes, rhetorically I did, yes.
SHOVELAND: Do you know the answer to that question?
TERRELL: No I don't and I don't think anybody does. Certainly the results of my recommendations of my Report are being examined by the Authority . . .

He then goes on to give a detailed explanation about the working groups, which I know he supports, and which will be finally reporting, as I told the Senate yesterday, on the 31st this month. I have quoted this before, and it is worth quoting again. He said:
I don't think there's anything in the regular public transport sector or the regional operators. . . which would indicate there's any cause for alarm at all. No.

I ask people who have a real interest in air safety, not just an interest in grabbing a headline—and this is Senator Bishop's major preoccupation in life; she does it very successfully, in fact, she has a higher media profile than any single member of the coalition including, I concede, the leader of the coalition—to read what Alan Terrell said this morning and compare it with what Senator Bishop said yesterday. People should ask the Chairman of the Board of the CAA whether he is prepared to make public his response to Alan Terrell's letter. Frankly, I do not think he intended to. But now that the letter has been dumped in the Senate by Senator Bishop, I do not think he has any choice. People might find it interesting reading.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the Minister why it has taken four warnings for him to take action. As well as Captain Terrell's letter that I tabled yesterday, I tabled one from Qantas which said that it was of `paramount importance that positive and permanent corrective action be taken immediately' to remedy problems associated with air safety standards, and that confidence in the CAA's safety regulations and standards division was `in serious jeopardy'. In other words, the Minister was asked to say why it has taken four warnings—I could say five warnings or six warnings, because Ansett has given one as well. Why has it taken since 1991 for the Minister to meet and convene such a meeting on the question of air standards which have clearly been deteriorating?

—As all honourable senators know, that question was fully answered. The CAA—and, indeed, the Government—constantly reviews the question of air standards. The CAA regularly gets the best experts in the world in aerospace management—there is one in Australia now acknowledged as one of the world's best in aerospace management—or air traffic control or any other area of air safety. It carries out regular reviews. I will repeat the answer I gave a minute ago about the response to the Qantas letter. The response was that the airlines met with the CAA, which Senator Bishop did not bother telling anybody yesterday. As a result of those meetings, they have six representatives of their peak body working on the working parties that are addressing the Terrell report. But nobody was told that yesterday by Senator Bishop.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories. I refer to the national forest policy statement that was signed last December by all governments except Tasmania. The policy provides for the establishment of a representative system of reserves of publicly owned old growth forest and wilderness areas by 1995 and, in the interim, that State forest agencies will avoid activities that may significantly affect areas of old growth forest or wilderness that have a high conservation value. Given that logging of high conservation value areas is continuing, particularly in Western Australia, Victoria and New South Wales, what action is the Minister taking to ensure that the policy is being enforced by State forest agencies? What has been the response to the letter sent by the Minister to State forest Ministers pointing out the requirement to protect areas of high conservation value? What action will the Minister take to ensure that those areas of high conservation value identified in the attachment to a letter are fully protected whilst the reserve system is being established?

—On 21 December 1992, the Minister, Mrs Kelly, wrote to the forest and environment Ministers in Queensland, Victoria, New South Wales and Western Australia pointing out the agreed policy under the national forest policy statement of protecting high conservation, old growth forests pending the establishment of a comprehensive reserve system. The Minister requested advice on State action taken to implement the policy and also invited State Ministers to bring forward proposals for Commonwealth funding to survey and assess forests for their conservation value.

PARA.TAB: Responses have been received from Western Australia, Queensland and New South Wales. The former Western Australian and Queensland forest Ministers were positive in their response to the Minister, agreeing that old growth forests require protection in their States. The response from the former New South Wales Minister for conservation and land management was extremely negative. The Minister is pursuing the issue with her State counterparts as a matter of priority. Moneys were allocated in 1992-93 and additional funds were provided under the Prime Minister's statement on the environment for the surveying and protection of old growth forests over the four years from 1992-93 to 1995-96.

Production discussions have been held with officials in Victoria and Queensland on proposals for assessing forests and their old growth values, funded under the NFPS, and have already commenced in the central highlands region of Victoria. Western Australia believes that it can identify areas without Commonwealth assistance. At the moment there would appear to be positive action occurring in Victoria and Queensland and probably Western Australia, but the situation in New South Wales is not what the Government would request. I know that Mrs Kelly will pursue vigorously with her New South Wales counterpart some better response.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations justify paying so-called performance based cash bonuses of up to $15,000 to highly paid public servants after 1 July while deferring indefinitely the election promise of an $8 a week pay rise to lower paid workers?

—The $8 a week pay rise referred to in the election was put in very explicit terms in the accord document, with which we are complying and with which I expect we will comply. Nobody could contend other than that we have had fair opportunity to debate the pros and cons of performance based pay during estimates committee hearings and during the Committee of the Whole stage of the estimates consideration. It seems to have been done exhaustively, if not thoroughly.

PARA.TAB: I do not have much more to add. It is part of the proposal to introduce and enhance efficiency and the devolution of management. It is quite consistent with the policy proposal—but does not go quite as far in that direction—put forward by the Opposition at the last election, which all Opposition members, including Senator Kemp, so enthusiastically supported. I am pleased to say that it does not take the principle as far as the Opposition did, nor does it go anywhere near as far as the policy of the governments of Victoria or New South Wales, which the Opposition so regularly supports.

Nevertheless, it is a recognition of efficiency incentives in the upper echelons of the public sector and is based on negotiations designed to reflect that. I am sure Senator Kemp would understand that the policy which his party outlined at the time of the election went much further in the same direction than this proposal. It was opposed to the $8 a week increase which we will support in accordance with the terms of the accord.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thought my question was quite clear. I asked the Minister to justify—and I think the community is interested in a Labor government justifying this—paying very substantial, secret cash bonuses of up to $15,000 a week to highly paid public servants while, during the election, the Government promised a pay rise of $8 a week to lower paid workers which has been deferred. How does the Minister justify the discrepancy? Could he also tell us when the $8 a week pay rise will become applicable.

—There is no accurate assertion in that supplementary question. I responded to all the things in the question which were in any way accurate, but there were almost none. Such assertions as there were in the supplementary question are wrong.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Defence been drawn to an assertion on ABC radio this morning that a number of submarine propellers had been `lost'? Can the Minister advise the Senate of the whereabouts of those propellers? Are they exhibits in the national gallery?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The compere of the local ABC radio program this morning made the following statement:

ANSWER.PARA: We do have a very good report on the whisper line that five propellers ordered for the major submarine program and under way in South Australia have gone missing.
The paper work shows they were duly shipped from Europe but they have yet to show up in South Australia and apparently it's causing some angst.

TALK.START.PARA: —You've got a screw loose.
—I will screw down Senator Baume on this one! It continues:

ANSWER.PARA: You can imagine the cost of submarine propellers—many, many thousands of dollars. It is a $5.5 billion dollar program. We understand five propellers have gone missing—we thought we'd float that one so to speak.

Obviously I checked that story. First, I can assure Senator Aulich that these propellers have not been picked up by Parliament House as artworks. Their aesthetic value is far in excess of anything in this building.

PARA.TAB: Where are the propellers? Very coincidentally, the first propeller was attached to the submarine in South Australia yesterday. The second propeller has been cast in the United Kingdom and is currently waiting to be machined. The third propeller is in Perth, Western Australia, at the premises of Timcast Pty Ltd awaiting machining. The production spare is still in the United Kingdom. It has been cast and is waiting to be machined. The remaining propellers have not yet been cast. When that has been done, they will be shipped again to Western Australia for machining.

All the propellers are on schedule, and so far have been delivered in accordance with the subcontract. I suggest that the radio compere sticks to what he specialises in—giving out petrol prices at the local service stations.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, relates to the redundancy payments that the Government is handing out to drive the numbers in the ADF down in order to save money. Part of those redundancy payments includes two weeks' payment for each year of service and a waiving of the provisions of section 23(3)(b) of the DFRDB Act, which applies a financial penalty for retirement before an age-rank point is reached. Given the fact that genuine voluntary retirements are going on and the penalties under section 23(3)(b) are really quite severe for premature retirement, how does the Minister equate that with what the Government is doing with the particular scheme that it is now running?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Faulkner Sen J.P.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: VETERANS' AFFAIRS; DEFENCE SCIENCE AND PERSONNEL

TALK.START.PARA: —These are voluntary redundancies. I report to the Senate that they are being accepted in overwhelming numbers by defence personnel. In fact, last year the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, approved voluntary redundancy programs for 510 Army personnel and 316 Air Force personnel. That was part of our program to assist the services to achieve smaller numbers yet maintain a more effective and, we believe, more efficient Defence Force. We have approved an additional voluntary redundancy program for up to 2,500 defence personnel. All those reductions will be achieved by the end of this calendar year.

PARA.TAB: The aim of our redundancy program is to reduce the numbers currently serving as well as opening up positions to allow recruiting at the base level and to allow normal promotions to occur. The program of the defence department will ensure that our Defence Force remains balanced in terms both of rank and trade structures. This program will comprise about 800 Army and 900 Air Force service personnel. Honourable senators may be aware that it also includes 800 defence civilians.

This program has been responded to very effectively by Defence Force personnel. I believe it is also appropriate to say that our responses to date have been commensurate with the numbers that we have targeted in our voluntary redundancy program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. With the greatest respect to the Minister, the question was about equity, not about numbers retiring on a voluntary basis or otherwise. Some of the statements about a balanced Defence Force are demonstrably incorrect. Waiving section 23(3)(b) means that officers are the only people targeted; other ranks are not. Only those officers who are in the DFRDB scheme, not in the MSBS scheme, are targeted. How can a government that has made such a great song and dance about non-discriminatory legislation in its term in office have an age-based retirement scheme in place? Would the Minister please answer the question regarding equity?

I do not think there is any evidence to sustain either of those arguments.

PARA.TAB: The value of some things within the tax system have been indexed while some have not; some things on the expenditure side have been indexed while some have not. I am simply saying that being on either side does not guarantee, protect, endanger or otherwise the value of the benefit. Its transfer from one side to the other does not do that. What it does in this instance is target the payment more accurately and make the benefit more apparent.

That was the point I was trying to make to Senator Tate, but I am happy to make it clear that there are, within the dependent spouse rebate and in the cash version of it which we will be introducing, very important equity implications. It is not merely a payment designed for welfare purposes. It has very important equity elements to it which must be a part of any consideration in future years of the level at which it is maintained. Nobody can give guarantees about what will be the real value of a tax deduction, a tax rebate or an expenditure in future years. There is no way that that effectively can be done. It requires decisions by Budgets and by the Parliament at the end of the day.

Whichever side of the Budget equation one is on, nobody can guarantee how well the value of the benefit will be sustained, but it is not endangered in any way by the transfer. Indeed, it will be enhanced and made more apparent; it will be better targeted in terms of being paid to the people who should be the recipients. TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to say that a contract with the Notion Picture Co. for a package of seven documentary films has been signed today. PARA.TAB: The films will take a strong Australian perspective on various conflicts from World War I to the Korean War. They will also boost general community awareness of the participation and contribution made by Australians to notable events and campaigns within these conflicts as well as to the overall outcomes of them. They will undoubtedly make a significant contribution to the national historical archive, especially in the areas of oral and visual history.

The initial aim is to have each documentary televised nationally about the time of significant wartime anniversaries or other commemorations and that will start with the 75th anniversary of the armistice in November 1993. The Notion Picture Co. will be the executive producer of the package which is provisionally titled The Australian Experience. It will also be aimed at video release, interactive formats and also—and I think Senator West will be interested in this—the schools educational market. The seven films will be directed by seven notable Australian filmmakers under the supervision of the Notion Picture Co.

The documentaries will be made from the points of view of those involved in the conflicts. They will include soldiers, sailors, airmen, women at war and also those who stayed on the home front. The content of each film will tell its own story and reveal a basic theme, conflict or advance in the development of our national heritage. They will cut across regional, ethnic and political boundaries in a variety of documentary formats.

The topics of the seven films that will be covered are: World War I, World War II, the Korean War, the Papua New Guinea campaign, the role of women during wartime, the RAAF in wartime and the Navy in wartime. PARA.TAB: As far as I am aware, there are no drugs that have been approved for both men and women by the Therapeutic Goods Administration and then listed on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme for men only. Drugs are recommended for listing on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee on the basis of the conditions for which they have marketing approval. The Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee is an expert body of health professionals—comprising both men and women, I might say—who make technical, scientifically based recommendations about the listing of drugs. To impute that these experts discriminate against women implies improper practice on their part, and that is patently absurd.

There is no discrimination by the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee and, therefore, the Government. Drugs are listed on the basis of their proposed use, not on the basis of which particular sex uses them. Obviously, some drugs are used only by women and some only by men. For example, oral contraceptives are intended for women. The expert bodies, that is, ADEC and the PBAC, make determinations on the use of drugs based only on the evidence submitted by the drug companies.

Senator Herron commented in his press release on the difference in the cost of Zoladex for men and women. Zoladex was first listed on the pharmaceutical benefits scheme in 1989 for the treatment of advanced cancer of the prostate. At that stage, this was the only indication the manufacturer had put forward to the Therapeutic Goods Administration for marketing approval. Prostate cancer was the only use the drug was approved for. Women obviously would not have received Zoladex at the subsidised cost.

In December 1992, the manufacturer applied to the Therapeutic Goods Administration for an extension of the marketing approval of Zoladex to include treatment of advanced breast cancer in premenopausal women. The Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee considered an application to list this drug on the PBS scheme for the treatment of breast cancer at its February 1993 meeting and subsequently recommended it for listing. This will be effective from August of this year, when the next schedule of pharmaceutical benefits is released. The Government did not discriminate against women who need Zoladex. The drug was first listed for a condition that only men suffered from. Its use has since been extended to treat breast cancer, a condition that both women and men suffer from. The Government will make the drug available to women from 1 August this year.

It is important to note that over the last six to seven years, Bass Strait has been characterised by intense competition between shipping companies, aggressive pricing policies, excess capacity and falling freight rates.
In fact, the Prices Surveillance Authority's 1992 report on monitoring of coastal freight rates concluded that Bass Strait freight rates had significantly declined in the period from 1986 to 1991.
Since the release of the PSA report, there has been an easing in the excess capacity experienced in the Bass Strait trade as ships have been withdrawn.

Recent freight rate increases have largely related to scheduled freight rates, which in general apply to ad hoc shipments.

Whereas I welcomed the words spoken by Senator Faulkner, I would very much like to see the content of these films to see how the record of Australians at war is treated.

One of the debates we have had in this Parliament over the past year and a half concerned the Australian flag. Senator McKiernan raised the issue that Australians have never fought under their flag. TALK.START.PARA: —On 25 May 1993 there was a discussion between the Chairman of Committees, Senator Colston, and Senator Macdonald concerning a ruling by the Chair that it is out of order under standing order 193(3) to suggest that any individual senator—or senators or Ministers collectively—has told lies.

PARA.TAB: It is a long-established principle that it is not in order for a senator to accuse another senator of telling lies or otherwise to state that a senator has deliberately made a statement that the senator knows to be untrue.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am on my feet! The rulings by past presidents are too numerous to mention. I draw attention to the various rulings set out on pages 217 to 223 of Odgers' Australian Senate Practice. Virtually every president since 1901 has had occasion to reiterate these rulings.
