The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Crichton-Browne)—On behalf of the President and in accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the following report of the Auditor-General: Report No. 37 of 1992-93—project audit—review of financial management systems. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The Auditor-General's report No. 37 is a report into a project audit on the review of financial systems applying in half a dozen or so government departments and agencies. By way of background, during 1991-92 the Australian National Audit Office undertook audits of five agencies which had installed over the past two years the same common proprietary, commercial, financial management system known as FINEST. The agencies covered in this audit were the Australian Federal Police, the Australian Securities Commission, the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions, the Department of Health, Housing, Local Government and Community Services and the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs.

PARA.TAB: The general conclusion of the Audit Office and the outcome of its audit into the five agencies was that generally the agencies were successfully utilising the FINEST software to support their financial operations and financial management. That was after looking into the purpose of the audits which was to examine the implementation and operation of the financial management system within the agencies to determine whether the financial management system was operated in such a way that the managers of the agencies could be assured that their accounting records were complete, accurate and valid, whether the system provided an adequate level of support for the management of the agencies' financial affairs, and whether the computer and support environment for the financial management system was effective.

As I said, the general conclusion was that the particular agencies that were audited were successfully utilising the FINEST software to support their financial operations and financial management. However, there were various deficiencies found in the agencies, the strength of which varied from one agency to another. I want to bring to the Senate's attention the one concerning the department for which I have shadow ministerial responsibility; namely, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. The Audit Office considered that the department needed to take strong and immediate action to avoid future problems with the integrity of its financial systems. It was in relation to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs that the Audit Office had the strongest comments of reservation as to how the whole thing was going.

The Audit Office found in relation to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs that it had not implemented the new system with a satisfactory level of environmental and manual processing controls to ensure the integrity of the financial data process. Specifically, the Audit Office concluded that there was a risk of improper account processing due to users having excessive access to the system. The Audit Office found that the department had not established adequate practices and procedures regarding the processing of purchasing and claims.

These deficiencies have been brought to the attention of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and, according to the Audit Office, the department has generally accepted the recommendations for improvement of the system so far as it applies to that department. In its response to the Auditor-General's criticisms, the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs indicated that since the completion of the audit, which took place in 1991-92, many of the control weaknesses found have been addressed. Also, the department reported that it is currently undertaking a major review of its approach to accounts processing, which should further tighten up on concerns identified by the Audit Office. So says the Audit Office. That is encouraging.

In commending the Audit Office for the review that it has done of these agencies, I point out that in relation to the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs there are obviously—and the department appears to accept this—numerous deficiencies in the administration of the department. I have expressed some concern in recent weeks about various operations of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs and its implementation of the migration program, a program of considerable importance, significance and sensitivity. It is very important indeed that departments charged with the sensitive responsibilities that departments such as the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs have do operate at a high level of administrative efficiency, otherwise people lose confidence in the programs that they are administering.

I welcome the positive response by the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs to the Auditor-General's comments and criticisms, and I can assure the Senate that the coalition will certainly be watching the progress in this matter with considerable interest in view of its importance.

SPEECH.PARA: Chair's Tabling Speech
Super Supervisory Levy
Mr President, Honourable senators would recall that almost two years ago the Select Committee on Superannuation was established with terms of reference which were both complex and comprehensive.

In November last year the Committee received a further reference to inquire into and report on the provisions of Statutory Rule No. 283 of 1992 which raised the superannuation supervisory levy from $40 to $200 per $500 000 of assets in superannuation funds.

The referral of the matter to the select committee was indeed a logical move on the part of the mover, Senator Alston. First the committee, in its initial report, Safeguarding Super, made a number of recommendations about the need for greater regulation of superannuation activities in Australia.
Arising out of that report and the Government's acceptance of most of the recommendations, was a need to devote substantial additional resources to the primary regulator of superannuation, the ISC.
The Committee and the Government also agreed that there should be a user-pays approach to the funding of the more interventionist ISC.
Consequently, the Government initiated Regulation 283 which increased the liability of superannuation funds in respect of the supervisory levy.
The Committee received 22 submissions on the levy and held a morning of public hearings at which the ISC, LIFA and ASFA gave evidence.

The inquiry process, whilst being an excellent opportunity to gain information on how the levy is set, also provided the Committee with a unique opportunity to assess the steps the ISC had taken towards becoming the principal supervisor of superannuation in Australia.

In this regard the Committee took a keen interest in the auditing program which the ISC proposes including those sectors of the industry which pose the greatest risk and other measures which it will need to take in becoming a proactive and, where needed, an interventionist agency responsible for securing over $155 billion of superannuation and approved deposit funds.

The general impression which I gained from the hearing is that the ISC is effectively coping with the many challenges which it now faces. I would remind the Senate that that organisation is probably the fastest growing office in the bureaucracy and growth of that magnitude presents organisational and staffing difficulties which the ISC appears to be overcoming.
I would now turn to the key recommendations which are contained in the report:

The first matter concerns the need for the ISC to consult more closely and widely with a range of industry groups when setting the levy. The Committee received a loud and clear message that the consultation was more of an ex poste than an ex ante setting of the levy process and we were unanimous that in future all of the key groups should be involved in the consultative process before a levy is determined.

One of the reasons for the rush of complaints following the determination of the levy (from memory the ISC received over 500 complaints after the announcement) was that for many funds it was a steep increase, in some cases approaching 400%.

The Committee believes that a phasing-in or averaging should have occurred and that way a smoothing out of increases should be able to occur in future. This would provide a certainty in planning both in the industry and the ISC.

The Committee further believes that the formula which is used to set the levy should take account of a number of parameters which have been identified in the report. If the Government takes heed of these suggestions a more efficient and equitable levy regime will be established.

One of these parameters, perhaps the most important, is the need to avoid cross subsidisation between small and large funds. Based on the evidence provided to the Committee this does not appear to have occurred.
Small funds, that is, those with assets not exceeding $500 000, pay a levy of $200 per year and receive regulatory benefits which the Committee values at $211.

Large funds contended that the increase in the maximum from $10 000 to $14 000 was unjustified. They told the committee that a levy of $10 000 implied a supervisory effort of more than one person day per week for a large but straightforward fund and that this was clearly beyond the current supervisory effort in relation to these funds. I sympathise with this comment but add that it is very difficult to allocate precisely the benefit on a per fund basis of the regulatory regime.

As we have stated in the report the overall integrity and security of superannuation generally is the aim of the government in this facet of intervention. If this can be achieved and fund failure is avoided, then $10 000 per year for a fund with assets exceeding $25 000 0000 is a small price to pay (.04 of a percentage point in fact). The cost of overall regulation vis a vis total fund assets is in the vicinity of .002 of a percentage point.

The committee looks forward to the Government's response to this unanimous report and it is our hope that the ISC will take on board both the spirit and the letter of the recommendations which have been made.

The committee has been a success for a number of reasons, and I will briefly elaborate on some of them.

PARA.TAB: The first, and not necessarily the most important, is that retirement incomes policy is one of the real challenges facing all Australians. Be they age pensioners, retired superannuants, workers on award super, recipients of the SGC, low income earners, part-time employees or public sector employees, many individuals have a natural interest in the fate they will experience when they retire. Therefore, intense scrutiny is being applied to this social welfare policy area.

Australia is not alone in this regard. In the United Kingdom pensioners worry about whether another Maxwell will occur. In the United States it is the performance of individual 401K plans and for how long the Government will go on guaranteeing unfunded private sector defined benefits schemes which have granted benefits in lieu of pay rises in the knowledge that the Government would pay up.

But in Australia, notwithstanding that there are some finetuning problems which the Committee will address in coming months, we do have in place the superstructure which will deliver self-provision and equity in retirement incomes policy. History will prove that the decisions of this Government in retirement incomes policy were correct. The record will also show the Select Committee on Superannuation was an important player in the launching of the Australian pensions flagship.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take this opportunity to move on behalf of the coalition the amendment standing in my name. I understand that the Government has quite a number of amendments to move. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 40, page 19, line 25, omit "and is taken always to have had", substitute "from 1 July 1992".

The amendment seeks to take away a retrospective element to enable taxpayers to rely on the black letter of taxation law. So I am pleased that in this place we have chosen not to extend the effect of repealed section 55 to before 1 July 1992.

PARA.TAB: The amendment has been drafted so as to achieve this aim in the least destructive fashion possible. It contains an express date so as to avoid any doubt about the extent of retrospectivity in clause 40 of this Bill. This is important for clarity, given the hive of legislative activity over section 55 this past year.

In my speech during the second reading debate on 19 May I said that retrospective legislation is wrong in principle. Also, in practice, if the Liberal National party coalition amendment to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill 1993, which is now in the committee stage of the Senate, is not accepted, those taxpayers who had prepared and lodged returns based on the letter of the law as it stood at the time will be obliged to lodge amended returns and adjust the tax.

This is one of the consequences of bad retrospective law. This illustrates why we should find that retrospective legislation is anti-ethical to good Government. Honest taxpayers who have, in good faith, predicated their behaviour and altered their material position on the basis of particular laws as they stood, may find this basis not only changed for the future, but also for the past. If we allow this sort of retrospective legislation to be passed, it will cause chaos which I am sure will be apparent to all honourable senators.

It ill becomes this place to rectify its legislative failings by legislative action, particularly in the tax area where people have met their commitments according to good law passed by this Parliament—according to the black letter of the law as such. It sends a message to the Executive that poor drafting causes taxpayers of this country problems enough without them being compounded by retrospective legislation. The past is indeed another country. They do things differently there. But with retrospective legislation, the way those things are done keeps changing over and over, depending on the Government's move. On behalf of the Liberal and National party coalition, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 40, page 19, line 25, omit "and is taken always to have had", substitute "from 1 July 1992".

This provision will remove the abhorrent, retrospective element of this amendment Bill in relation to broadbanding. Although the Government may claim it was never intended, there are many taxpayers in this country who do not read press releases issued by treasurers and who do not have the opportunity to read explanatory memorandums. They would go to their solicitors who would have a copy of that legislation. On the basis of that legislation, they should be able to prepare their tax returns with certainty and not find that a subsequent parliament overturns those provisions, even though those particular provisions may not have been the original intention of the Government at the time the legislation was passed.

PARA.TAB: It is a reflection not only on the Government but also perhaps on us as senators for not picking up these sorts of things. Nevertheless, taxpayers should be able to rely on that law as being good law at the time. I do not mind legislation being changed—I am quite happy for it to be changed—as long as it does not change retrospectively. That is the purpose of the coalition's concerns.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Watson for his contribution. Certainty before the law is a very important and vital issue, particularly for this Senate chamber. Although what we are dealing with is not of major significance, except to those who are involved, we should be standing by the principle of certainty before the law. Senator Watson referred to clause 40 which repeals section 55 to make it clear that rates of depreciation determined on an effect of life basis that correspond with a broadbanded rate cannot be increased to the next highest broadbanded rate. Had we left that section as it was, it would, as Senator Watson said, have required substituted or additional returns by the taxpayer. I assume that Senator Watson's amendment would ensure that it would take effect for this taxation year and onwards. The Minister may be able to explain why, when we are talking about retrospectivity and the operative date being 1 July 1992, that should not be 1993, if we are truly looking at the question of retrospectivity.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to the committee for being late. For the first time in my life I was surprised by the speed with which the Senate did something. I have had two such surprises in one day, the other one not being from the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was used the other day.

—No; it is a reasonably cavalier approach that is being taken because we are flagging it and saying, `Look, here is an anomaly which you might all be able to go back and use' but not in the way the legislation intended—as an incentive to people to make decisions that are socially responsible. It is about saying, `Those decisions that you made on the basis of the understanding we all had as to what the legislation meant, you can now retrospectively get a bit more money for'.
—You can't tell that to taxpayers out in the country.
—That is what those opposite are saying.
—They are entitled to rely on the law as they read it.
—Both Senator Watson and Senator Panizza know—although Senator Panizza is not officially responsible for this, he is an interested participant in the debate about tax—
—I know, you know, we know; but what about the fellow out there?

—I do not understand the point of Senator Watson's interjection. I am happy to pursue it further, but we are saying that the original announcement was clear. PARA.TAB: The original provision is simply unclear. It is neither rational nor responsible to endanger the revenue for no social purpose and not to change the provisions to encourage investment. People will not change their behaviour as a result of this; this is the tax implication of decisions that have already been made. TALK.START.PARA: —You are stretching a long bow on that.

—I do not want to be diverted by Senator Panizza's misunderstanding. The fact is that there is no argument. —Under self-assessment, neither the Minister nor the Australian Taxation Office really would be aware of taxpayers who had lodged returns on the basis of the literal interpretation that they are entitled to take by virtue of the looseness of the terminology used in the legislation. PARA.TAB: Because of the many changes and the repeal of section 55 provisions, we had to move them in such a way as to have the least disruptive effect. But people are entitled to rely on an exact interpretation as they see it. There was no vagueness about it. It may not have been the intent of this Parliament to have been so generous—true. Some taxpayers may have been somewhat surprised at the apparent generosity or at the extension. But, after all, broadbanding was about providing a more generous uplift to the next broadbanded classification. If they were on a particular broadbanded classification, they were not entitled to go up to the next one. That was the intent, but that is not how it was worded when this legislation was passed.

All we are seeking to do is remove the retrospective element; there will be no great loss of revenue because it will apply only in a fairly restricted period. They will now be forced to go back, pay their accountants money and change all of their records. As a result of some sloppy drafting by the Government, those people will have to carry that expense.

I think it is about time we looked at our priorities. Who should be carrying the cost of these sorts of errors? Should it be the taxpayer or the commissioner in this case? TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Watson in this matter. PARA.TAB: The Senate should scrutinise this sort of action taken by the Government, especially if the Government intends to continue to put legislation through the House of Representatives with very little scrutiny in that chamber. TALK.START.PARA: —I raise another matter on the Bill in its entirety—in particular, clause 15. This relates to proposals to allow the matching of immigration data and tax data. PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: ANSWERS TO SENATOR KERNOT'S QUESTIONS ON 21 MAY 1993 TO THE MINISTER REPRESENTING THE TREASURER ON TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT Bill No 2 1993

PARA.EMPHASIS: CLAUSE 15 OF THE BILL AND PROPOSED NEW PARAGRAPH 16(4)(HD)

SPEECH.PARA: Q1:The paragraph only allows the divulging of information to the Secretary of the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs [DIEA] "for the purpose of assisting in locating persons who are unlawfully in Australia". Does this mean that only information concerning those who are unlawfully in Australia can be divulged?

A1:Yes. The purpose in proposing an information sharing arrangement between ATO and DIEA is to match data on illegal entrants or overstayers with ATO records to obtain the best available residential and workplace addresses of illegal entrants and in this way facilitate their location. The ATO will only divulge information relating to residential and workplace addresses.
Q2:Why doesn't the legislation limit the information to that of illegal entrants or overstayers?

A2:The legislation does not specifically limit the information to that pertaining to illegal entrants or overstayers as the terminology "persons unlawfully in Australia" covers the term "illegal entrants". The term "illegal entrants" currently includes, under section 14 of the Migration Act 1958, any non-citizen who enters or remains in Australia without authority or who overstays any authority. A new term "unlawful non-citizen" will be used from 1 November 1993 upon commencement of the Migration Reform Act 1992 to describe all non-citizens unlawfully in Australia.
Q3:Is it not a fact that the wording is so wide that the personal information of people other than the illegal entrant or overstayer could be supplied under the provision?
A3:See A1 and A2. The wording of the paragraph is confined to "persons who are unlawfully in Australia".
Q4:Will the Government amend the legislation to ensure that only information relating to the illegal entrant under investigation can be divulged?
A4:Based on A3, the need to amend the legislation is not warranted.

Q5:The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs Media Release of 17 December 1992 specifically states "DILGEA will not have access to tax file numbers (TFNs) under these arrangements." Does the legislation ensure that the officers of DILGEA cannot have access to TFNs.
Q6:Why doesn't the legislation specifically prohibit the provision of TFNs?
Q7:Will the Government amend the legislation to ensure that TFNs cannot be provided?

A5-7:There is no need to amend clause 15 of the Bill to specifically prohibit DIEA officers having access to TFNs. The reason being is that sections 8WA and 8WB of the Taxation Administration Act 1953 prohibit the recording, requesting, disclosure and use of a person's TFN in unauthorised circumstances. DIEA officers are not authorised to request, receive or use TFNs.

For example, quotation of TFNs may be a precondition to receiving any Commonwealth income support payment. Such a payment would include payments by the Departments of Social Security; Veterans Affairs; Employment, Education and Training. Use of TFNs for that purpose are specifically authorised by sections 8WA and 8WB.
Q8:How does an illegal entrant to Australia obtain a TFN? Does the Tax Office check that the applicant is entitled to work in Australia? lf yes, what is the procedure? If not, why not?

A8:An illegal entrant applies for a TFN in the same way as other taxpayers using a TFN application/enquiry form. Subsection 202BA(2) of the Assessment Act provides that the Commissioner may refuse the application if he is not satisfied as to the applicants true identity. There is no legislative provision to allow the ATO to check whether the applicant is entitled to work in Australia.

Further, the Commissioner is unable to refuse to issue a TFN on grounds of nationality, residency or work status. Where an overseas passport is given as one of the proof of identity documents, the currency of the visa is checked. If the visa has expired, the passport is not accepted as a valid proof of identity document for TFN application purposes.
Q9:Why doesn't clause 15 also allow the provision of information in respect of contravention of visa requirements?

A9:At this stage, the Government considers that a priority in establishing an information sharing arrangement between the ATO and DIEA is to permit information sharing for the purpose of identifying and locating persons unlawfully in Australia. Any proposal to extend the arrangement to include those persons working in breach of their visa conditions will be examined in the light of the experience with this arrangement.
As explained in A8, overseas passports with expired visas are not accepted as valid proof of identity. The Tax Office does not take details of expired visas or of persons tendering such documents.
Q10:Is it the Government's intention to amend the law in the future so as to allow the provision of information to the Secretary of DILGEA concerning contravention of visa requirements?
A10:Not at this stage. See also A9 above.

Q11:Could the Minister please give an indicative statement of how this provision would be used in practice? That is, what information would be provided by DILGEA to the Tax Office, what would the Tax Office do with the information, what enquiries and procedures would the Tax Office then undertake, what information would then be provided to DILGEA by the Tax Office?
A11:The provision, enabling exchange of information between the Commissioner and DIEA, is expected to work in practice as follows:

PARA.TAB: DIEA information in respect of overstayers without an application or review pending (ie; those persons who have already breached the Immigration Act) will be supplied to the Tax Office; and
The information to be returned by the Tax Office to DIEA will be limited to residential and employment addresses of those overstayers.

SPEECH.PARA: As people can see from these answers, the question of access to tax file numbers is specifically dealt with at length. It will not be lawful for the Taxation Office to provide a person's tax file number under this provision. The answers specifically state that the information to be provided by the Taxation Office is limited to the residential and employment addresses of the overstayers. Considering that these people are already in breach of the law, we believe that this is not an unreasonable proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am opposed to section 15 of the legislation which proposes to amend section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act by allowing the Commissioner of Taxation to provide the immigration department with employment and residential address details of illegal immigrants. I am opposed to this amendment for at least two reasons.

PARA.TAB: First and foremost is that it is a dreadful precedent. It has been the proud boast of the Taxation Office that it went about its business, and its business was the collection of tax, and nothing would prevent its pursuit of the collection of tax. It has not been, so far as I know, able to disclose to other agencies information relating to taxpayers which it has for its particular purposes. I think that was well and truly understood by taxpayers, whether they were illegal or legal. It was understood by those illegal immigrants who were working who, at least in those circumstances, were paying their taxes.

I hasten to say that I have no truck with illegal immigrants. The activity of the immigration department in attempting to track down persons who are illegally outstaying their visas and are illegally in Australia is quite worth while. But that is not the point here. The point is that this legislation requires the Australian Taxation Office to provide this sort of information to the immigration department.

The second reason that I am concerned is that this amendment could well result in some adverse consequences for the labour market, particularly so far as other workers are concerned. I referred to this in the second reading debate. I had hoped that the Government would provide some analysis to this chamber of the ultimate impact of this proposal, having regard to the questions that I raised during the second reading stage, but we have not been provided with any research by, for example, the Bureau of Labour Market Research into the possible impact of this provision.

I believe there is every reason to think that this measure will create a large pool of illegal immigrant labour, completely outside the protection of industrial award systems or any workplace agreements. At present, without fear of detection, such illegal immigrants can pay their taxes, obtain a tax file number, provide it to the employer and have pay-as-you-earn deductions made each week. That money goes into the coffers of the Australian Government. What will be the result of this measure in that respect? Has the Government considered the possibility that it will create a pool of illegal immigrant labour?

This pool of exploitable labour may well be used to undermine employment conditions for ordinary Australian workers, just as farm labour in American States such as California has operated to undercut employment conditions generally. I referred to this matter in my speech in the second reading debate. I do not want to labour that point or remind honourable senators about the history and the struggles of the trade union movement in California against this problem of illegal, non-taxpaying immigrants, but I feel that we are entitled to an explanation or an analysis from the Government as to whether it has considered these unintended consequences. There are other aspects, of course; for example, the health dangers in respect of illegal itinerant labour in the United States.

I do feel that the Government should have referred this legislation for consideration by the Department of Industrial Relations or the Bureau of Labour Market Research, to give just a couple of examples, to see what possible effect and unintended consequence this proposal might have. But ultimately I am opposed to the proposition because I believe that it is just the thin end of the wedge whereby the Taxation Office can be used by other agencies and other government authorities to obtain personal information of taxpayers which otherwise they would not be able to obtain.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, I thank Senator Lees for her comments. The questions which the Democrats raised were legitimate ones. I am pleased that the responses reassured them and met their concerns. Although I do not agree with the conclusions he has come to, the points which he made in the second part certainly raise a very important question which needs to be taken very seriously. I do not, on balance, share the conclusion. But, if an unintended consequence of this legislation were of the type which he described and of any significant size, it would be an unwelcome exacerbation of a problem we already have in Australia at the moment on a somewhat small scale.

We are all aware that already there are people working in Australia who are outside the tax and industrial relations systems of the country. There have been attempts to crack down on that type of thing. In my period as Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer I think the group of people who came to see me who received the least sympathy were, in effect—without, of course, disclosing any details—representatives of employers who had been raided because they were employing some of these people. That did not seem to evoke much concern with me or anybody else I could find.

So I take very seriously the point that Senator Harradine raises. It is something we would need to give attention to. But we also need to consider the consequences of not acting in this matter. I know Senator Harradine is not neglecting that. He is saying that on balance he thinks the risk is too great to take. I understand that.

From the Government's point of view, the standard arrangement for any proposal such as this to amend legislation—and I was not in the Cabinet at the time this decision was made—would be that it is distributed for coordination comment and sent to both the Department of Industrial Relations and the department of employment to see if they had concerns which would warrant not proceeding with legislation of this sort.

So, even if I knew, I could not bring here all the details of whatever concerns they may have raised. I am simply saying that the opportunity for those concerns to be raised is provided in the process. If the concerns were raised, the Cabinet obviously made a decision, on balance, to proceed. There would be a number of people, not least of whom was the then Minister for Industrial Relations, who would have been aware of the same sorts of issues as those which Senator Harradine raises and about which I am concerned because of his experiences with some of the issues that we are both aware of.

I do not, in any way, minimise the significance of the issue; I just come down, on balance, on the other side. I do have some disagreement with Senator Harradine on the thin end of the wedge argument. I do not want to minimise the significance of any extension of the provisions of section 16 of the Act which enables people to receive information from the Taxation Office. But, in a very limited, careful way, over the years there has been a limited extension of the capacity of this information to be used in very tightly controlled ways for narrowly defined purposes, and this is consistent with that. Section 16 designates the individuals and the circumstances.

Last year some members of the Parliament argued that in a couple of examples we had not extended this provision far enough—I am not saying Senator Harradine did; I cannot remember how he voted. It is always a difficult issue to decide when there is pressure to pursue evident criminality and concerns about the mechanism. Of course, the tax Act is not the only place where that conflict arises. It arises in the area of phone tapping and all sorts of other issues, which I do not want to raise. We have to be very vigilant in ensuring that the balance does not go too far in terms of invasion of civil liberties of the citizen.

For the reasons that have been outlined by the Government, but perhaps more effectively or comprehensively outlined in response to the questions raised at the committee and by the Democrats, I think the balance of the argument is in favour of this limited extension. Therefore, although I understand Senator Harradine's concerns, I believe that we should proceed with the proposed section.

TALK.START.PARA: —I turn to part 2 of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 2) and refer to the extension of fringe benefits tax exemptions on child care. Quite clearly, I support the extension of the exemptions. As I mentioned in my speech at the second reading stage, the law regarding child care expenses and taxation is totally illogical. Child care paid for by a salary sacrifice arranged between the employee and the employer is a tax-free fringe benefit. To the extent that this Bill extends that, I support it. But an employee is not allowed a deduction for his or her child care expenses.

PARA.TAB: I understand that the committee stage of this Bill is not the time to go into the full detail of the tax treatment of employee child care expenses. Nonetheless, there are anomalies in the fringe benefits tax legislation. This is the time to raise those anomalies, and I have raised them. I would like answers from the Minister in respect of some of these anomalies. The first anomaly to which I draw attention again is the definition of `child care facility' in section 136(1) of the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act. The definition excludes child care provided by an associate and excludes care at the place of residence of any of the children.

Apparently, it is okay provided the children are taken out of the home and cared for somewhere else. That is an anomaly. It is a very strange situation. It is not difficult either to see that this could create problems. For example, if the rules of the family day care scheme were altered to allow a day carer to care for the children of an employee in that employee's home, that would not be an exempt fringe benefit.

I know of one employee and employer. The employer is willing, because of the circumstances of the situation, to pay for a proportion of the payment required by a child carer. The wife of the employee is at home and clearly needs assistance. That assistance is now being provided by the employee having to take time off to go home during working hours. That employee is a very valued employee and the employer wants to rectify this situation by providing a payment for a day carer and it would be better in all of the circumstances for the children to be cared for in their own home.

I understand, of course, the problems relating to the Government's guidelines on family day care schemes, and that is another issue that we will have to take up at some other stage. But if that issue were resolved, then the legislation that we are considering now would not exempt that payment from tax under the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act.

There should be, in my view, an amendment to this legislation which would alleviate or eliminate that anomaly. I further believe there should be an amendment to the legislation to avoid any difficulty which might be caused by the former exclusion of children over six years of age. The removal of that restriction is consistent with the Government's objective of extending the exemption for child care to after school care for school children.

Another logical reform in this area would be to extend the exemption generally to any form of child care, whether formal or informal, and I ask the Minister whether the Government is considering such an arrangement. We should not presume to tie family child-care arrangements to any particular bureaucratic form and we are doing that here. The definition in the legislation with which we are dealing will discriminate against those employers who pay for child care for children in the home of the employee. I would like to hear what the Minister has to say about that and how the Government can justify such an anomalous situation.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —The important thing to realise about this matter—I am not pretending that Senator Harradine does not understand this, because he does—is that we are dealing with the Fringe Benefits Tax Act. In very broad terms, without pretending to be the world expert on all the issues that are involved, that is why we were slow to make this extension. TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that I have broader concerns about the equity in this area but I am dealing specifically and in focused terms with the issue that is currently before us—that is, the extension of the child care exemption for fringe benefits tax to everything, barring the caring of the children in the home.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, we did. We congratulated the Government on its new form. It's a big improvement in terms of drafting.

—Let me take the opposite view, because I fear that the Opposition may not have seen what is behind all this. The Government is ultimately making these items not tax deductible items but government handouts. Once that happens, they are in the hands of the Government and charitable organisations will not be able to open their mouths in respect of government policy.

PARA.TAB: The object of clause 8 of the Bill is to repeal section 78 of the Income Tax Assessment Act and substitute a `more readable version'. I do not believe that the provisions are any more readable. In fact, I feel that they are less so because they have no inherent logic. In terms of taxation theory, all gifts to charity ought to be deductible. Charities serve social and public purposes just as much as public spending programs do. If income is redistributed voluntarily within society, the demand on government programs is so much the less.

I also note that section 78 is listed by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) as a tax expenditure or subsidy. That is nonsense. All section 78 does is allow deductibility to PAYE taxpayers for gifts to some selected charities. Taxpayers with income from property do not need section 78 to make tax effective gifts to charity. They can either gift property to charity, carrying the income with it, or pass the income from property through a trust to their favourite charity. Rather than being a tax expenditure, section 78 simply creates a level playing field between income from personal exertion and income from property with regard to its redistribution for charitable purposes.

Because the gift provisions as redrafted are so complex, we ought to consider a simple amendment to save taxpayers the trouble of reading them. We ought to consider replacing the proposed section 78(4) with a general deduction for charitable gifts, as in the United States of America. Section 78 should provide a level playing field for all charities and all taxpayers and not be subject to the whims of a particular government of a particular day amending a particular Act such as this. All gifts to charity should be equally deductible for all taxpayers.

From the point of maximising social welfare, a neutral tax system ought to recognise and respect all forms of non-government income redistribution. Voluntary redistribution of income to charitable causes is more efficient in many cases—and I would suggest most cases—than government taxed financed redistribution.

I ask the Minister to explain to the Committee of the Whole why the Industry Commission has received a reference from the Treasurer to inquire into charitable organisations. Apart from wondering what the word industry has to do with charity, I would like to express my concern about the Industry Commission assuming, without proof, that tax allowances for charity are some sort of concession.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sometimes donations to such bodies as the Conservation Foundation finish up down some other hole.

I want to ask the Minister why the Government has chosen to send to the Industry Commission this reference to inquire into charitable organisations. What does it have to do with the Industry Commission?

TALK.START.PARA: —I want some explanations regarding clauses 46 and 47. At the hearing of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration last Friday, it might be recalled that I tabled some draft amendments relating to the capital gains proposals introduced into this Bill. The first of those amendments concerned the application date of the amendments to remove a number of potential anomalies in capital gains provisions to prevent double taxation. Of course, those amendments are most welcome. However, I have a problem in relation to clause 47 of the Bill which restricts the application of the amendments to assets `created after 25 June 1992'. This does have a very narrow application.

PARA.TAB: I wonder whether that word `created' was fully intended or whether it was disposed of. Because the problem that I have is that if the Government is to insist on the word `created' the Government is effectively recognising that these changes are consequential upon the changes to the catch-all provisions in capital gains under section 160M(6) and (7). It would appear that it will have a very restrictive application in terms of eligible termination payments.

What is said in the application clause in this drafted form should have been said in the substantive provisions. This gives rise to some difficulties that taxpayers are likely to encounter. If we are to make changes which have such a fundamental restrictive nature they should be in the substantive provisions of the legislation rather than in just the application clauses. We recognise that it has a concessionary application but, if one reads sections 45 and 46 prior to 47, one will see that the application is so narrow that one will wonder why it was put in, quite frankly. It will not have much application at present; perhaps it will in the future. Perhaps this word `created' should be further examined in the light of my comments.

Clauses 52 to 56 propose a number of amendments to 160ZZO capital gains rollover rules for assets transferred within company groups. The amendments represent the Government's fifth attempt, I must say, at getting section 160ZZO right, and it is not right yet. The amendments are intended to overcome a number of anomalies under the current version of section 160ZZO. Naturally, the Opposition supports these in principle for that reason. But the problem I wish to submit now is that the amendments introduce a further anomaly.

Under the new section 160ZZO(a) a deemed disposal will occur where an asset has been rolled over within a subgroup of companies and the subgroup leaves a wider group. Under the present rules, no deemed disposal would generally occur in this situation. If we look at the real world, perhaps this could be intended to cover a situation such as the Adelaide Steamship Co. Ltd where there is a rollover provision and where Woolworths will soon come out on its own. I think one could have the worst of all worlds where the rolled over asset could finish up in Woolworths and capital gains tax would still be paid, which would be quite ridiculous.

At this point I think the problem raises a number of complex technical issues, so it will not be easy. I have sought some assistance from Price Waterhouse in Melbourne and, as such, produced a redraft of section 160ZZO(a) that I believe could eliminate the problem. We tabled the proposed redraft of the section at the hearing of the finance and public administration committee last Friday.

The point of my contribution now, and I would like Senator McMullan to reiterate, is that he then advised me that the Government would not support the amendments—so we did not press them—but he gave an undertaking that the matter would be examined during the winter recess with a view to introducing further amendments to resolve the issue early in the Budget session. I think it is appropriate that we reintroduce them at this stage. While it is with some reluctance that I accept the Government's proposal, I am sure that the additional technical resources the Government can bring to bear on this problem, with its technical advisers and others, will be of some benefit. My reluctance in accepting the Government's proposal on this is that the Tax Office has had the problem for some time, perhaps dating back to some time in April—something like five weeks ago. Given that this afternoon we were able to execute expeditiously the amendments, the taxation office should perhaps have directed its mind to this issue a little earlier.

More fundamentally, I wish to draw to the attention of the Minister the fact that the amendments apply from 16 December 1992. Almost one year will have elapsed by the time the Government further considers this matter during the Budget session and introduces the legislation. Therefore, the amendments I tabled on Friday would not have had an adverse impact on taxpayers, but they would prevent the inappropriate application of the deemed disposable rules under section 160ZZOA as proposed by this Bill to subgroups of companies. I, therefore, seek an assurance from the Minister that any further amendments introduced during the Budget session to correct the anomaly of the subgroups will apply, preferably from 16 December 1992. I thank the Minister for his previous assurance and I hope he does not mind my seeking it again in this particular forum.

PARA.TAB: In October 1992 the Minister for Finance agreed to make an act of grace payment of $3,904,531.30c to Queensland Alumina Ltd, commonly known as QAL. This amount represented the interest on customs duty paid under protest on imports of crude oil. The duty, amounting to $28 million, was refunded following resolutions of a related tariff classification issue in the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The tariff classification dispute centred on whether imports of oil where topped crude duty free or fuel oil dutiable. QAL imported 14 shipments of oil from the United States between 1986 and 1988 and paid duty under protest of $28 million.

In July 1987, QAL agreed, at the request of the Australian Customs Service, to defer its AAT appeal pending the outcome of a related AAT case concerning Savage River Mines, which are located in Tasmania. Following an AAT decision in September of 1987, that imports by the Savage River Mines from the United States were not dutiable, the ACS appealed to the Federal Court, which accepted the ACS case, and referred the matter back to AAT for re-examination.

In February 1989 the AAT decided in favour of Savage River Mines and the company undertook action in the New South Wales Supreme Court to recover the duty paid plus interest. In October 1989 the Supreme Court directed the duty of $296,000 and interest of $196,000 be paid to Savage River Mines by ACS. ACS advised QAL on 17 March 1989 that refunds would be paid subject to evidence being produced that the QAL product was the same as that considered in the AAT.

Following the Savage River Mines Supreme Court decisions, the ACS obtained refining history details of the oil imports by QAL, to assess whether the goods accorded with those in the Savage River Mines case. This was confirmed by mid-1990. It took some time for QAL to produce the evidence and the $28 million duty payment under protest was refunded in total by June 1990.

The ACS has recognised the opportunity for QAL to pursue separate legal action in a State Supreme Court for payments of refunds plus interest, so it therefore moved quickly, within 10 days, to pay the refunds once the evidence was produced. Supreme Court actions preclude claims for interest except as part of a judgment for payment of a principal sum.

In response to representations by QAL in early 1990, ACS advised that there was no provision in the customs legislation to pay interest on the duty refunded. QAL subsequently appealed to the Ombudsman in September 1990. The Ombudsman recognised in February 1991 that an ex gratia payment should be made.

The then Minister for Finance, after considering a report from a committee comprising the Secretary of the Department of Finance, the Secretary of the Department Administrative Services and the Comptroller-General of Customs, decided in October of 1992 that an ex gratia payment of $3.9 million should be made to QAL for interest forgone. The amount of $3.9 million interest was assessed by the Ombudsman in June 1991 after considering claims by QAL and Customs.

The interest reflects the lower end of the interest range—12.5 per cent was the midpoint of 12 to 13 per cent, which is used consistently by the Queensland Supreme Court—and there was a shorter period of application, with interest paid only on the period from payment of duty under protest to 17 March 1989, the date ACS agreed to pay refunds. It should be noted that the rate of interest being applied by the New South Wales Supreme Court at the time was 19.5 to 21 per cent.

In a separate development, Savage River Mines, also known as Dahlia Mining Co., appealed to the AAT concerning imports of oil from New Zealand in December 1987. In June 1991 the AAT accepted the ACS view that it was fuel oil and dutiable at $600,000. This was successfully appealed to the Federal Court, which held that the duty be refunded. In a subsequent related action in the New South Wales Supreme Court in August 1992, Dahlia Mining was awarded $454,000 interest on the duty paid. Notwithstanding those cases, the ACS moved in February 1989, following the initial AAT case, to put the tariff classification issue beyond doubt by amending the customs regulations. Since then, topped crude oil can be imported duty free only if it is used as refined feedstock.

TALK.START.PARA: —Henry Lawson wrote of `noble and heroic endeavour frowned down or callously neglected'. There is no greater example of this than the Government's treatment of rural families who depend on the wool industry for their livelihood. There is such determination to hang on in the face of such adversity; there is such weariness and disappointment; there is an abundant contempt and wilful deception shown in the Government's response.

PARA.TAB: Members of every parliament in the country have described the trauma facing rural Australia and called for action. Last November, when the RAS Bills were before the Senate, I explained the inadequacy of RAS to reach more than a minority of growers. Yet the Government was not moved.

The media has introduced the plight of many rural families to city people through detailed coverage of what life is like battling drought, low commodity prices and the hangover of high interest rates. The Government moved a little. The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Simon Crean, eventually returned from holiday to do a drought quickie tour. This resulted in a bandaid assistance package and the appointment of the Pied Piper of economic rationalists, Professor Garnaut, to weave a second dry spell over the future of the wool industry.

It is six months since the RAS Bills were debated; the drought is six months older; the wool price has dropped another 40c; and poverty sits at many more rural tables. The Minister charged in on his white horse and distributed a limited largess, but the problems are greater now than ever.

The Rural Adjustment Scheme Advisory Council, after an overwhelming response to its deliberations, has made its report to the Minister, which he has refused to release. The Minister has seen with his own eyes the damage done by drought, low prices, falling asset values and high debt. He knows, he has seen, but he is not unduly moved, judging by his response. He must have a heart like the biblical pharaoh who would not release the Israelites from bondage.

I have seen shoddy treatment of various groups in the community by the Government, but never have I seen such callous disregard and neglect of an enormous problem, and never have I seen such plain hustling when it comes to selling the Government's response. The Government's response to the wool industry is one of minimum comprehension of the problem, minimum effort to address it and maximum PR to camouflage it. To those who accuse me of overreacting, to those who think the April wool package dotted all the i's and crossed the t's, let me make a number of points clear. Six months ago the Minister's office provided me with the following figures which, together with other documents, I seek leave to table.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the time, there were 15,000 farmers receiving some RAS assistance. The Government estimated that by the end of the financial year 6,000 to 7,000 farmers would finish their contracts, but this would be offset by 3,000 to 4,000 new entrants. In line with that reasoning, the Government has confirmed this week that there are now 11,500 farmers on RAS. That is a drop of 3,500 people. That means that 7,000 farmers, as predicted, no longer receive RAS.

PARA.TAB: What has happened to those farmers? Have they survived? How are they living now? The Government simply does not know. It does not have the information, and I tried unsuccessfully at the last two estimates hearings to find out. The Government does not know how many of these 7,000 farmers have left the rural sector, how many have managed to stay on without RAS, or how many reapplied to RAS and were knocked back because they were no longer viable.

The Government has no mechanism in place to determine what has happened to half of RAS's needy clientele and this is a huge black hole in the system. How can a government make effective policy without knowing the effects of this policy? Last Friday the Minister's office informed my office that of the 11,500 farmers currently on RAS, approximately 6,300 are specialist wool producers. There are over 60,000 primary producers in Australia who grow some wool. Of these, ABARE classifies 18,000 as specialist wool producers who derive most of their income from the sale of wool and sheepmeat. They hold 48 per cent of the nation's flock. Hence, some 28 per cent of specialist woolgrowers are receiving some RAS.

The fact is that the Government has been reaching less than one-third of specialist producers, owners of just under half of the nation's flock. This must be interpreted against several indicators of the industry's financial position. Ninety-one per cent of sheep industry farms made a loss in 1991-92. Average farm loss was $39,660. The wool price has fallen below 400c—it has recovered a bit over the last couple of weeks—which represents a cost to the grower of at least $2 for every kilo sold. Even sheep industry farms at full equity are forecast to make a loss.

Six months ago the average equity of properties in south-west Queensland was 58 per cent. Income distribution tables from ABARE highlight that very few are making a profit and very many are making a substantial loss. There are also very few in the intermediate range, which is where RAS is targeted. The RAS market is shrinking as it daily becomes impossible to be classified as viable, the prerequisite for RAS assistance.

The facts are startling. In Queensland, 50 per cent of sheep farms are forecast to make a loss of more than $50,000 in 1992-93. This is based on an optimistic wool price of 503c a kilo. The current price is 452c a kilo. In New South Wales 9.9 per cent of sheep farms are forecast to make a profit; one per cent will make more than $50,000. In Victoria, 0.6 per cent of sheep farms will make more than $50,000. Gone are the images of Merc-driving graziers and Gold Coast holidays. The industry is in a state of collapse. The Government's response was to provide some RAS assistance, up to $30,000, to less than one-third of the specialist growers or guardians of 16 per cent of the nation's flock.

Assistance under RAS is refused on viability grounds. One can be too viable and not need RAS. Anecdotal evidence backed up by the ABARE estimates that close to 10 per cent of producers might make a profit—even if a small one—allows me to make a harsh assumption that the top 10 per cent would be ruled out of RAS eligibility for being too well off. We know that just under 30 per cent of woolgrowers are currently receiving RAS so they must have been deemed viable under RAS guidelines. That means the Government has deemed the remaining 60 per cent of producers are not wanting assistance or are unviable. It is acknowledged that there will be some farms that are debt free, some with little debt, but with wool prices at present levels and only nine per cent of woolgrowers making a profit, these farms are increasingly falling into the need area of RAS.

Let us consider the new wool package and its `exceptional circumstances' funding. The Government estimates that a total of 5,790 woolgrowers will be eligible to share $39.6 million—an average assistance of $6,840 per grower which might cover the fuel bill for six months. This assistance is available for a maximum of 12 months and is topped up by the States to varying degrees.

In addition, 780 growers are expected to be eligible for `exceptional circumstances' drought provisions and share in an allocated $5 million at an average of $6,410. This assistance is available for a maximum of six months. It must be remembered that this is in addition to the normal RAS allocation.

A very important point is that while there may be some new RAS entrants under the exceptional circumstances provision, industry suggests that it will be mainly existing RAS recipients who will benefit from the April wool package. The main reason for this is the similarity of eligibility guidelines and the difficulty in meeting viability provisions. In last week's estimates committee hearing a RAS officer said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . you are running off the back of current arrangements with individual farmers. It will be a top-up in most cases.

Therefore, even after the much vaunted wool package, the Government will still be reaching an approximate one-third of the specialist wool industry. The wool package does not widen the net of RAS recipients; it simply offers a little more support to the minority that can prove viability according to their respective and restrictive guidelines.

PARA.TAB: What about the other two-thirds of the industry? A very small percentage, as I have identified, will have positive cash flows due to off-farm assets. Some may have no significant debt. This group is shrinking as these assets are used to finance their wool concerns through the prolonged price slump. As a result, more of this top group are filtering down into the RAS target area.

Victoria at least expects many new RAS applicants from this group in the months to come. As conditions deteriorate, one-third of the industry that the Government is assisting is moving up the industry hierarchy. Previous RAS recipients from lower down the scale are increasingly unable to show long term viability and are falling off the RAS ledge. The Government's decision to leave 60 per cent of specialist wool producers without assistance means that 10,800 growers are left to struggle on as best they can.

There are very few options available. Wool costs $2 a kilogram more to produce than to sell. Women find work if close to a town where there is any work, while the men try to keep the property going and the stock alive. This income can, paradoxically, restrict eligibility for RAS. There are between 4,000 and 4,500 farmers or spouses who manage to meet the JSA assets criteria. There is no breakdown available on how many of these are woolgrowers. However, by taking JSA a farmer loses his eligibility for a re-establishment grant offered to those who have no choice but to leave the industry.

The Government likes to talk about its farm household support assistance category as though it were an attractive, generous offer to poverty stricken farm families. Paid at the same rate as the JSA, it is nevertheless a commercial government loan, unless the farmer can sell his property within nine months. The last thing a farmer needs who wants to stay on the land but cannot get RAS, along with 60 per cent of his industry, is another loan. As a consequence, farm household support is not very popular. There are only 209 people receiving it at the moment. Producers are also scared that once they apply for FHS, the QIDC or similar State lending authorities will move to foreclose.

It is ironic that a farmer can be deemed unviable for a subsidy but eligible for a loan. Some will inevitably leave. It is surprising, however, considering the worsening conditions, to discover that the actual number of producers taking re-establishment grants to leave the rural sector—some 326 in the nine months to March 1993—is way down on the Government's estimate of 1,400 for the whole year. The average grant has been $32,906 and they cling on desperately and stubbornly. There are thousands of farmers who cannot meet the JSA asset criteria and who reject the farm household support option because it merely puts food on the table while they are selling up. It is this group that causes me the most concern. They must be making terrible personal sacrifices to feed and clothe themselves and keep their places going.

The bush is where I believe the real heroes are. Half the specialist wool industry is living on nothing—a dream and a prayer. Shires cannot keep subsidising towns while their rates remain unpaid. Telephones, the lifeline for isolated families, are being cut off, along with power in a few instances. Vehicle registrations are lapsing. There is a limit to the leniency and charity of authorities, financial institutions and aid agencies.

By ignoring 60 per cent of producers in his latest package, Mr Crean has effectively begun to remove people from the industry. In the city, they could get the dole and not have to pay it back or sell up their home and move a thousand miles away. In the bush, there is no equivalent welfare benefit.

Non-government agencies such as St Vincent de Paul, the Salvation Army and Lifeline are attempting to fill the gap and put their resources into action, but they are spread very thinly. It is important to note that the reduced spending power of 60 per cent of the wool industry which is ignored by the Government is having a disastrous effect on rural towns.

I have outlined the minimal effort that the Government has put in to address the substantial problem. I can only think of two reasons for this totally inadequate response: firstly, the Government does not care; and, secondly, if the Government were to open its eyes to the enormity of the problems, it would find them too difficult to solve. The Government prefers a tunnel vision approach. As was so quaintly outlined by an officer in the estimates hearings:

SPEECH.PARA: The way the calculations have been made is that we have targeted a group of farmers, we have put some sort of numerical expression against that group, and we have used an average level of the expected rate at which they will draw assistance and that has been grossed up on an annual basis.

`Some sort of numerical expression' against a group of farmers is the Government's way of saying that it decided at the stroke of a pen what percentage of farmers it would help to stay in the industry. In this case, it is 30 per cent.

PARA.TAB: In doing so, the Minister has classified 60 per cent of the industry as not getting help. He is happy to leave 60 per cent of the great Australian wool industry to suffer alone through the worst ever price and seasonal conditions. He has executed a coup de grace by appointing Professor Garnaut to oversee the long-term issues. This leads to the assertion I made earlier about the use of maximum PR to camouflage the Government's poor response.

The Minister's whirlwind tour of drought-affected properties was a tremendous public relations feat. His wooing of Margaret Greer was in the best traditions of Labor politics and led the media to focus on her as being the voice of the bush. Once the wool package was released, Mrs Greer praised the Minister for listening and allocating funds to the problem. She said that he had given her the hope to stay and fight.

I do not know Mrs Greer's particular situation. I heard her speak at a meeting in Charleville where she expressed her concern and anguish on behalf of woolgrowers throughout Australia. She has become a media focus and has brought the plight of farmers into the homes of millions of Australians. She has to be congratulated on that. But if her property had been able to access RAS funds in the past, along with the 60 per cent of drought affected growers in Queensland, it is highly unlikely that she would now be able to access RAS funds.

During the Minister's visit, she mentioned his telling her that funds would be available for people in her situation. He could have been referring only to JSA or farm household support, which is a short-term loan to enable people just to put food on the table until their property is sold. A repayment contract is signed before the support is drawn down. Under present conditions, no woolgrower will take on such a loan unless he is prepared to leave. How else would a grower be in a position to repay the Government's generosity?

With little analysis of how individual woolgrowers would be assisted by this package, the Minister enjoyed an ill-fitting hero status, being painted as a saviour of the wool industry. Nothing could be further from the truth. He has sentenced 60 per cent of the industry to go it alone, and he has resisted the hard options at all times. The biggest cop-out of all was to hand over the reins to Professor Garnaut—the same man who advocated the removal of anti-dumping arrangements together with all tariffs and export assistance. His duplicity has extended to placing information in the Queensland Country Life, the Land and the Stock and Land and giving alarmingly misleading information about benefits that rural people can apply for.

The Minister is callously exploiting the situation for the maximum political mileage. Once again, as with the Margaret Greers of the industry, he is raising false hopes and whispering promises that can never be fulfilled.

This is a very serious matter. I have tabled papers from the Queensland Country Life of 20 May 1993 and other papers. In a box headed `RAS: what it can mean to you' were two articles. One is headed `Special drought relief extended' and the other `Help in a crisis'. This information was given out by Mr Crean's department. The `Help in a crisis' article contains a list of special financial assistance available to people in crisis situations from the Department of Social Security. After some investigation, it becomes apparent that hardly any farmers could possibly qualify for such measures.

There are three categories listed. The first is the special benefit. Senator Evans told me in the Senate on Tuesday that in general terms it is unlikely that farmers would easily come within the relevant criteria. There is no chance of any farmer successfully applying under this program.

The second category is a hardship provision which makes allowance for greater assets when combined with little income. However, this scheme is in the process of being wound up, and will be by November this year, and is being replaced with farm household support, which is quite different, being a loan. The 244 farmers and spouses currently under this program will be transferred to the household support scheme. I have a letter from the department saying that no new applicants for modified JSA will be accepted after 20 March 1993 and that, in the case of hardship provisions of JSA and NSA, there is a requirement that the farm be offered for sale. Hence, it is impossible to apply for this category of benefit. It is a straight-out mistruth to tell people that they can apply for a non-existent benefit.

The third category of benefit provides funds to community welfare agencies to help in crisis situations. It is not a means of regular support. Senator Evans admitted that he had no data on this, only anecdotal information.

It is totally misleading to put this information in the State's leading rural newspapers and imply that the Government has all sorts of funding programs available for rural people when in fact none of these three benefits—one of which is obsolescent and one has never been an option for farmers—can be accessed in any significant capacity. It is a cruel hoax on struggling farmers.

The Government is advertising benefits which it cannot deliver. It is indicative of the Government's self-knowledge that it is offering rural Australia a very poor deal indeed. Why will the Minister not release the RASAC report? RASAC is a publicly funded body and should be accountable to the Parliament. Is it because of his reluctance to be accountable on his meagre response to the report?

Why has the Government left 60 per cent of the wool industry without support or assistance? These 10,800 families are facing immediate and pressing needs—to stay on the land, to stay fed and to keep their children educated and clothed—and they are doing it without assistance. Why can the Government not see that the removal of drought from the natural disaster scheme is an act of which only God is capable? This relentless drought is certainly a disaster, not only for the woolgrowers but also for many other industries. It is compounded by the man-made disaster which is this Government's pitiful response.

The Government has sent a majority of Australian woolgrowers to the industry's Gallipoli. They have been left in the trenches with insufficient provisions and no sign of reinforcements. The general is a thousand miles away in Canberra and is happy to accept the high casualty rates. He makes a quick trip to the front, slaps the diggers on the back and promises that help is on the way. They initially believe him and cling to every last straw, but then slowly realise that the general has gone back to his desk, leaving them to fight alone against impossible odds.

These people do not want to accept the farm household support because they do not want to leave their posts. They are fighting for their families, their way of life and the remnants of generations of investments. They would rather fight to the last than succumb to being a POW in the city dole queues.
