TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to speak on a matter which the WA branch of the Custom Brokers Council of Australia has raised with me relating to optional port lodgment legislation which has passed through this Parliament but which has not yet been brought into law. I will not read all of my speech tonight because the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (Senator Bolkus), who is at the table, has agreed that I can incorporate it, but I would like to make a few brief comments.

PARA.TAB: This matter relates to the effect that this optional port lodgement will have in terms of the ease with which drugs come into Australia. I believe that is a very serious possibility. It is something to which both sides of the chamber should give very serious consideration. I have been approached and well briefed by Kelly Monte on behalf of the Western Australian branch of the Custom Brokers Council of Australia. Tomorrow every member of this chamber will receive a special report on the danger of increased drug traffic in their States. This is a very serious document. It contains an enormous amount of hard fact. It clearly points out the increased presence of drugs in Australia, particularly those drugs that have been intercepted as they have come across our shores.

This report also highlights the fact that only a very small percentage of imports arriving into this country are inspected. I will give one example. A mail bag, which has a value placed on it by the sender, is not even inspected when it comes into this nation. This Senate needs to have another very careful look at the possible impact of this legislation. The Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht), who is the Minister responsible, has already been briefed by this organisation. I will read one page of this submission that all senators will receive tomorrow. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: We ask you to make a personal representation to Senator Chris Schacht in the interests of your state and the Customs Brokers Council of Australia (WA, SA, QLD and TAS), asking him not to introduce OPL and give an undertaking that he will not introduce it into the future.

I would agree that that seems to be a very demanding request. I think that after going through the submission and reading the speech that will be incorporated in Hansard tonight, every person in this chamber, in this Parliament and beyond will have a careful think about what is happening in this area. I will read out a couple of passages from this speech. The first one states:
In 1971/72 the customs seized 162 kilograms of drugs. In 1991/92 they seized 5071 kilograms of drugs—an increase of 3130 per cent.
The changes that have been passed in that legislation will make it even easier for the drugs to come across our shore. Another passage states:
Amphetamines seizures rose by almost 1000 percent in one year.

Part of this speech which has been prepared for me—I have read it very carefully and I approve of it—quotes from the Australian Federal Police annual report. That report in itself is instructive reading. I quote this particular passage as follows:

"The AFP's focus will remain the identification and pursuit by proactive investigation of major drug importation syndicates. Particular attention will be given to evidence which suggests increased smuggling and availability of cocaine.

Last year the golden Triangle countries produced 3000 tonnes of opium. It is estimated that this was refined to about 200 to 250 tonnes of heroin, of the `No. 4' white powder which is preferred in Australia.
Federal police say that there is no shortage of heroin in source countries.
There appears to be no shortage of drugs in Australia so it is logical to assume that massive amounts of drugs are being brought into the country through normal import channels.

Federal police intelligence investigations in Western Australia, carried out over many months has identified a pattern engaged in large importations of heroin through ships. These investigations have already led to the arrest of two men and the seizure of 3.2 kilograms of heroin.
Police and customs both talk of highly efficient and well planned drug imports through crime syndicates in Italy, Japan and South America.
I could go one quoting from this document, but I will not.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, one of the very important things that faces the Australian community today, particularly our young people who are under an enormous amount of social pressure, is the increased advent of drugs into the country. As senators, we have a responsibility to look very closely at the matter I have raised here tonight. I seek leave to incorporate my speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Drugs is a massive problem in Australia—it is one that is growing year by year.
It is a problem which surpasses party political barriers, but if a particular party found an instant solution for the problem it would receive landslide support from the voting public.

Yet strange as it may seem a legislature such as this House has passed legislation which will support the growth of the drug industry in Australia and make it far easier to traffic drugs in Australia than to get picked up for drunk driving.

Our state and Federal police forces see the horrific outcomes from the widespread use of drugs. They know that legislative and budget constraints makes their work much harder, but through loyalty towards both their minister and our system of Government they remain silent.

Smaller states such as Western Australia, South Australia, Queensland and Tasmania along with the Northern Territory will suffer the most under this legislation—Optional Port Lodgement (a part of the Customs Act Amendment) which as yet has not been put into operation.
Optional Port Lodgement means customs documentation can be lodged at any port in Australia. Currently it must be lodged at the port where goods enter.
With this system Customs Brokers lodge documents and can detect irregularities.

Major importers want OPL to allow them to lodge all documentation direct from their head office. Under OPL most documentation for Australia will be lodged in Sydney or Melbourne. Melbourne and Sydney have problems with current workloads. Far more work will mean far less checks on documentation.
For example of 48,410 importers to Australia handled through the Sydney office customs target 120-a-year for compliance audit checks.

Twenty years ago there were 5000 customs officers, collecting $466 million in import duty and clearing 1.6 million passengers. Today there are still 5000 staff who collect $3.3 billion and clear 10 million passengers.
In 1971/72 the customs seized 162 kilograms of drugs. In 1991/92 they seized 5071 kg of drugs—an increase of 3130 percent.
Currently Customs Brokers around Australia provide an invaluable service to Customs Officers in the search for drugs.

The Australian Customs Service has stated that not only have a number of reports of suspected unusual activities been made to customs, but a major drug find in WA was the result of information received from the industry.
Late last year Customs Brokers signed an agreement with customs to assist in the fight against illegal drug trafficking.
The campaign called Frontline engages Customs Brokers in a 32 point check on imports—all physical—which can detect drugs.
At the time of the introduction of the campaign, customs said drugs had a big community cost attached.

"Costs of the trade (drugs) are borne by the whole community, they are reflected in the crime rate, insurance and health costs, absenteeism and that large part of the tax dollar which goes towards health and law enforcement," Customs documents stated.
Only 1.5 percent or 150 containers out of every 10,000 are checked for drugs.
Any airbag entering Australia with a value under $50 (the value placed on it by the sender) does not even need documentation for customs.
A look at Federal police drug seizures tells the complete story.
In the 1990/91 financial year the Australian federal police seized a total of 1.7 million grams of drugs.
One year later (the latest published figures) that increased to 5.1 million grams, an increase of more than 300 percent.
Although the most interesting aspect is not the massive increase, but the type of drugs seized.
Amphetamines seizures rose by almost 1000 percent in one year.
The amount of cannabis dropped by a half although this was obtained from about 30 percent more seizures.
However, the mostly `imported' cannabis resin increased by a massive 1100 percent to 4.5 million grams.

The latest Australian Federal Police report lists drugs as originating from: South America, Papua New Guinea, Holland, Singapore, Thailand, New Caledonia, New Zealand, Tonga, the United States, Fiji, the United Kingdom, Jamaica, the Middle East, Bali and Nepal to name a few.
The police talk of an importation and a drug distribution network based in Darwin for Heroin imports to Australia.

They talk of a growing problem of the importation of the popular `New Guinea Gold'—a type of Cannabis which is exchanged in Australia for weapons—used by Guerilla forces against the elected government in New Guinea.

The report details the innovative methods used to import drugs: They have been found in sandals, inside the frames of exercise bicycles, and inside olive containers, international mail, an engine block, sports field rollers, swallowed by mean and women, and in the soles of running shoes.
I quote from the Australian Federal Police annual report:

"The AFP's focus will remain the identification and pursuit by proactive investigation of major drug importation syndicates. Particular attention will be given to the evidence which suggests increased smuggling and availability of cocaine.

Last year the golden Triangle countries produced 3000 tonnes of opium. It is estimated that this was refined to about 200 to 250 tonnes of heroin, of the `No. 4' white powder which is preferred in Australia.
Federal police say that there is no shortage of heroin in source countries.
There appears to be no shortage of drugs in Australia so it is logical to assume that massive amounts of drugs are being brought into the country through normal import channels.

Federal police intelligence investigations in Western Australia, carried out over many months has identified a pattern engaged in large importations of heroin through ships. These investigations have already led to the arrest of two men and the seizure of 3.2 kgs of heroin.
Police and customs both talk of highly efficient and well planned drug imports through crime syndicates in Italy, Japan and South America.
A likelihood of increased air traffic into Australia through Port Hedland and Broome this year already has Federal Police worried.
There is severe pressure on Customs, Federal Police and State police.

Currently if someone wants the WA police to investigate a fraud complaint in Queensland—they have to pay police air fares to investigate—this gives some indication of the budget constraints on state police.
If this House puts unjustified pressure on enforcement agencies to save a few dollars for big business then this House is responsible for opening up drug trade in Australia.
We may just as well licence drug traffickers and get a few bob out of them.
The second argument to the story is the Customs Brokers themselves.
It will be another case of big job losses around Australia and with these job losses will go expertise on the Australian wharves which can never be regained.
Customs Brokers have had their businesses on hold for some time awaiting the outcome of electronic lodgement legislation.
Ironically only last week the same legislation was before the United States congress.
Over there Customs Brokers marched on Washington.
Customs Brokers in the United States are having the same problems with improved technology.
American customs see the courier firms and international air bags becoming a major problem for the United States.
The president of the American National Customs Brokers and Forwarders Association summed up the issue with this:

"The NCBFA believes you have to keep the importer at the heart of the System—and his broker inextricably linked to his interests and fully accountable for the honesty, accuracy and efficiency of the entry system.
Drugs is an ever increasing problem facing Australia. It is an emotional issue and rightly so it is an attention grabber.
However there are many other ways that Customs Brokers provide community protection in the course of their everyday work.
They ensure quarantine regulations are observed, they ensure that goods entering the country meet Australian standards, they are ever watchful for prohibited imports such as weapons.
We as a Chamber must ensure that integrity remains with the importation of goods into Australia. That is why we are here. Optional Port Lodgement must be stopped at all costs.
